Centurion Bidco S.p.A., a joint stock company (società per azioni) incorporated under the laws of Italy (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €      million in aggregate principal amount
of its    % Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “Notes”). The gross proceeds from the Offering will be used, together with cash on balance sheet, to (i) repay in full and cancel the indebtedness
incurred under the Bridge Facility (as defined herein), including accrued interest thereon, and (ii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Offering and the Bridge Facility Refinancing (as
defined herein). The amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility were used by the Issuer, together with a portion of the proceeds from the Sellers’ Reinvestment (as defined herein) and cash on
balance sheet, directly or indirectly, to fund the Be Acquisition (as defined herein) and to pay fees and expenses in connection with the Be Acquisition and the entry into and drawing of the
Bridge Facility, as described in more detail herein. See “Summary—The Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds.”
The Notes will bear interest at a rate of % per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on each of and, commencing on, 2023. The Notes will mature on     , 2028.
Prior to, 2025, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or any portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to,
but excluding, the date of redemption, and Additional Amounts, if any, plus a “make whole” premium. In addition, prior to, 2025, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of
the Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Notes issued) in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued
and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of redemption, and Additional Amounts, if any. Furthermore, prior to, 2025, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the original principal amount
of the Notes with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price set forth in this Offering Memorandum, provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the original principal amount of the
Notes remains outstanding. At any time on or after, 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum.
In addition, in the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof
plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for any series of Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal
amount of the outstanding Notes of such series validly tender and do not withdraw the Notes of such series in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in
lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes of such series validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders of Notes, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that
remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes in such offer. See “Description of the Notes—Optional
_Redemption.” Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase all the outstanding Notes, at a purchase price equal to_
101% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.”
The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and
will rank pari passu in right of payment with the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including the Existing Notes (as defined herein), the Existing Revolving Credit
Facility (as defined herein) and the Existing Term Loan (as defined herein). Upon the initial issuance of the Notes on the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein)
and to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be guaranteed (the “Guarantees” and, each a “Guarantee”) on a senior secured basis by the Company (as defined
herein) and Overlord Bidco (together, the “Guarantors”). The Guarantees will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the relevant Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is not
subordinated to such Guarantee, and will be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness or obligations of each of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that does not guarantee the
Notes. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles and to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Company also guarantees the Issuer’s obligations under the Existing Notes,
the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and the Existing Term Loan, and Overlord Bidco guarantees the Issuer’s obligations under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, in each case, on a senior
secured basis. Upon completion of (x) the Engineering Merger (as defined herein), if any, MergerCo (as defined herein) will assume the Issuer’s obligations under the Notes and the Guarantee
of the Notes by the Company is expected to be released and (y) the Engineering-Overlord Bidco Merger (as defined herein), if any, the Guarantee of the Notes by Overlord Bidco will be released.
In addition, upon completion of the Engineering-Overlord Bidco Merger, Overlord Bidco will no longer be a separate legal entity, and therefore the Overlord Funding Loan II (as defined herein),
and any security interest granted in respect of it, will cease to exist. The pledge on the shares of Overlord Bidco held by the Company (or MergerCo, following the Engineering Merger) will also
cease to exist as a result of such merger, and the Notes will instead be secured by a pledge to be granted within ten Business Days of the Engineering-Overlord Bidco Merger on all the shares of
Be or the entity resulting from the Be-Be Opco Merger (as the case may be) held by the Company (or MergerCo, following the Engineering Merger).
On or about the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, by the Initial Collateral (as defined herein). Within 30 days
from (and excluding) the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, by the Post-Issue Date Collateral; provided that if
the Engineering Merger becomes effective prior to the date on which the Post-Issue Date Collateral has been granted, the Notes (x) will not be secured by the Post-Issue Date Collateral and (y)
will instead be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, by the Post-Engineering Merger Collateral within the later of 30 days from (and excluding)
the Issue Date and ten Business Days from (and excluding) the Engineering Merger Date. Within ten Business Days from (and excluding) the Engineering Merger Date (as defined herein), the
Notes will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, by the Post-Engineering Merger Collateral (as defined herein). Subject to the Agreed Security
Principles, the Initial Collateral and the Post-Issue Date Collateral also secure, and following the Engineering Merger, the Post-Engineering Merger Collateral will secure, the Issuer’s obligations
under, the Existing Notes, the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations (if any) and the Existing Term Loan on a pari passu basis. Each of the Initial Collateral, the PostIssue Date Collateral and the Post-Engineering Merger Collateral is further described under “Description of the Notes—Security.” Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined
herein) and subject to applicable laws, the holders of Notes will receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral (x) only after the lenders under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility
and counterparties to certain hedging obligations (if any) have been repaid in full and (y) on a pari passu basis with the holders of the Existing Notes and the lender under the Existing Term
Loan. In addition, subject to applicable laws, the Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. Subject to the terms of the Indenture, the
Intercreditor Agreement, and to applicable laws, the Collateral may be pledged to secure future indebtedness. The Guarantees and the Collateral will be subject to certain material limitations
pursuant to applicable laws as described under “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.” See
also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral—Once granted, the Guarantees and the Collateral will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and
_may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Revolving Credit Facility_
_Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security.”_

## GLOSSARY OF SELECTED TERMS

In this Offering Memorandum we use certain industry-specific terms and abbreviations when discussing
our business, the meanings of which are indicated below:

**“advanced analytics” ........................................** A part of data science that uses high-level
methods and tools to focus on projecting future
trends, events, and behaviors.

**“AI” ....................................................................** Artificial intelligence.

**“AR” ...................................................................** Augmented reality.

**“big data” ...........................................................** Extremely large data sets that may be analyzed
computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and
associations, especially relating to human
behavior and interactions.

**“blockchain” ......................................................** A system in which a record of transactions
made is maintained across several computers
that are linked in a peer-to-peer network.

**“cloud” ...............................................................** A network of servers to and from which data
can be uploaded and downloaded.

**“cloud-based services” ......................................** Services that are operated from the cloud.

**“core process specialists”..................................** Specialist in our customer’s business processes
that are considered of core importance.

**“CRM” ...............................................................** Customer relationship management.

**“cybersecurity” .................................................** A set of technologies, skills, processes and
structures required to protect data, applications
and infrastructure from unauthorized access,
damage or attacks.

**“data visualization” ..........................................** The presentation of data sets in a manner that is
understandable to humans.

**“digital enabling technologies” ........................** Technologies that enable the digital

transformation of companies by enhancing AI,
advanced analytics, cloud, cybersecurity, IoT,
robotic process automation, AR / MR / VR,

## PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION

**General**

The Issuer was incorporated on March 20, 2020, in connection with the Engineering Acquisition. As of
the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating
activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets, other than the shares it holds in the
Company and its receivables under the Existing Funding Loan and the Overlord Funding Loan I, or
material liabilities, other than those incurred in connection with its incorporation, the Engineering
Acquisition and the transactions related thereto, including the Existing Notes, the Existing Revolving
Credit Facility, the Existing Term Loan, the €210.0 million deeply subordinated shareholder loan
granted by TopCo to the Issuer in 2020 in connection with the Engineering Acquisition, and the Bridge
Facility.

As the Company has only been consolidated within the Issuer’s results since July 23, 2020, which was
the Engineering Acquisition Closing Date, in this Offering Memorandum, we present historical
financial information for the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries for periods prior to such date,
and for the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries for periods following such date. Accordingly, unless
otherwise stated, all references to “we,” “us,” “our” or the “Group” in respect of historical financial
information in this Offering Memorandum are to (i) the Issuer and its subsidiaries, for each of the years
ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, and (ii) the Company and its subsidiaries, for the year ended
December 31, 2020.

In particular, this Offering Memorandum includes the English translation of the Issuer’s audited
consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, which include
comparative unaudited financial data for the year ended December 31, 2021, which have been prepared
in accordance with IFRS (the “2022 Audited Financial Statements”). The 2022 Audited Financial
Statements have been audited by Deloitte & Touche S.p.A. and are the only financial statements that
are included in this Offering Memorandum.

This Offering Memorandum also includes certain references to, and financial information derived from,
(i) the Company’s audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31,
2020, which include comparative financial data for the year ended December 31, 2019, which have
been prepared in accordance with IFRS (the “Company’s 2020 Financial Statements”) and (ii) the
Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021,
which include comparative financial data for the year ended December 31, 2020, which have been
prepared in accordance with IFRS (the “2021 Financial Statements”). The Company’s 2020 Financial
Statements and the 2021 Financial Statements are available on the Issuer’s reporting website but not
included in this Offering Memorandum. The Company’s 2020 Financial Statements, the 2021 Financial
Statements and the financial figures derived therefrom included in this Offering Memorandum are
affected by certain accounting errors, as further described under “—Accounting Errors” below, and
therefore the comparability thereof with financial figures derived from the 2022 Audited Financial
Statements is limited.

Given the different scope of consolidation, the financial results of the Company and the Issuer are not
directly comparable. In particular, the 2021 Financial Statements are not directly comparable to the
Company’s 2020 Financial Statements due to the different scope of consolidation, which resulted,
among other things, in the 2021 Financial Statements also including indebtedness and cash at the level
of the Issuer (including indebtedness under the Existing Notes, the Existing Term Loan, the Existing

to the Issuer in 2020 in connection with the Engineering Acquisition, and associated interest payments,

**Accounting Errors**

In September 2022, we became aware of certain discrepancies between budgeted and final financial
data as of August 2022 relating to the Company’s Finance industry vertical and its subsidiary Nexen
(which is part of the Finance industry vertical). As a result of such discrepancies, we initiated a process,
with the assistance from external advisors, in order to verify the accounting methods used for specific
jobs within the Company’s Finance industry vertical and Nexen.

This verification process, which was completed at the end of the fiscal year 2022, identified certain
accounting errors relating to the 2022 fiscal year and previous fiscal years, which resulted in an
overstatement of the Company’s consolidated balance sheet assets and operating profits. On this basis,
management determined that it was necessary to make certain corrections to the financial statements
and applied IAS 8 (Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors), which governs,
among other things, how to recognise and represent errors, including those from previous years.

The verification process concluded that the accounting errors resulted from the allocation of costs in
our internal management system, which mainly led to the recognition of revenues:

(i) relating to jobs that were not supported by any underlying contract, including by allocating to

such jobs costs that were unrelated to them (e.g., costs relating to other existing jobs), and by
recognizing corresponding revenues on our accounting systems; and

(ii) in advance of their accrual period.

As a result of such errors, the Company recorded non-recoverable balance sheet assets in the form of
invoices to be issued and work-in-progress (recognized in the financial statements under current assets
in the item “Customer contract assets”), which could not be and were not invoiced to customers.

Based on the results of the verification process, we quantified the following accounting effects:


-----

(i) an overstatement of the Group’s operating profit and EBITDA for the year ended December

31, 2022, of €10.9 million; and

(ii) an overstatement of the balance sheet assets as of January 1, 2022 of €46.0 million.

Both effects were corrected in our 2022 Audited Financial Statements.

While it was possible to allocate the effects of the accounting errors that occurred during 2022 to the
financial year ended December 31, 2022 due to the availability of current information on the progress
of the Finance industry vertical’s contracts, we were not able to allocate with certainty the €46.0 million
overstatement of balance sheet assets as of January 1, 2022 to any prior periods because of the way our
management systems close out jobs and of the lack of traceability inside the system for such an
accounting error.

With respect to these accounting errors relating to fiscal years prior to 2022, we applied paragraphs 42
to 47 of IAS 8 as it was not possible to accurately and reasonably determine the impact of such errors
relating to such fiscal years. The Company therefore concluded that it was appropriate to adjust the
opening balance of assets and shareholders’ equity as of January 1, 2022, in order to reflect the lower
value of the assets of €46.0 million, by setting up a specific adjustment provision with the opening
shareholders’ equity as of January 1, 2022, as a balancing entry.

As a result of these events, the independent auditors’ report for the consolidated financial statements of
the Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 included in this Offering Memorandum,
contains an emphasis of matter paragraph in relation to the accounting errors due to the inability of the
Issuer to allocate the effects of such errors to periods prior to the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022.
See also Note 1.1 to our 2022 Audited Financial Statements describing the correction of major errors
under IAS 8.

With respect to the accounting treatment of the correction of errors relating to fiscal year 2022, these
were corrected prior to the approval of the 2022 Audited Financial Statements, as required by IAS 8
(par. 5), according to which “potential errors of the current financial year discovered in the same
_financial year shall be corrected before the publication of the financial statements is authorised.”_
Therefore, we corrected the relevant items in the income statement for the year ended December 31,
2022, generating a corresponding impact on the operating profit and EBITDA, which was rectified by
€10.9 million.

These accounting errors were the result of intentional misconduct by certain members of the
management of our Finance industry vertical. As of the date of the Offering Memorandum, such
members of management of the Finance industry vertical are being or have been replaced and these
accounting errors did not result in a material impact on the relationship with our customers.

Following completion of the verification process carried out with respect to the Finance industry
vertical, we deemed it prudent to carry out further verification processes on all the other verticals of the
Company with the assistance of external advisors whose work was completed by the end of 2022. As
of the date of this Offering Memorandum, no incorrect accounting practices similar to those uncovered
in the Company’s Finance industry vertical and Nexen were identified. However, as a result of such
verification process, we prudentially made specific provisions of approximately €7.0 million (of which
€6.1 million relating to contract work in progress and €0.9 million to invoices to be issued) in our
balance sheet as of December 31, 2022, in respect of some positions relating to assets accrued mainly
in previous years and not invoiced, exclusively attributable to technical/commercial issues that emerged
during the execution of the jobs. Such €7.0 million provisions did not impact our consolidated EBITDA
for the year ended December 31, 2022.

As a result of the correction of the accounting errors in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements as
summarized above and the inability of the Issuer to quantify the above-mentioned corrections on net


-----

income and shareholders’ equity for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, the consolidated
financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 contained in the 2022 Audited
Financial Statements included in the Offering Memorandum is not fully comparable with (i) the
financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Audited
Financial Statements and the 2021 Financial Statements, and (ii) the financial information as of and for
the year ended December 31, 2020 derived from the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements. For the
same reasons, the financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 derived from
the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements is also not fully comparable with the financial information
as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements and
the 2021 Financial Statements. Neither the 2021 Financial Statements nor the Company’s 2020
Financial Statements are included in the Offering Memorandum.

This Offering Memorandum also includes certain financial information as of and for the two months
ended February 28, 2022 under “Summary—Recent Trading,” which is compared to corresponding
financial information as of and for the two months ended February 28, 2023. Such information as of
and for the two months ended February 28, 2022 was impacted by the accounting error described above
due to our inability to allocate the impact of the accounting error on the 2022 Audited Financial
Statements on a quarter or monthly basis through the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022. As a result,
the financial information as of and for the two months ended February 28, 2022 presented herein is not
fully comparable with the financial information as of and for the two months ended February 28, 2023
(which was not impacted by the accounting error), and therefore you should not place undue reliance
on such information.

As a consequence of the foregoing, throughout this Offering Memorandum, we have either marked any
such consolidated financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021,
including any related averages, ranges and growth rates, with an asterisk (“*”) or we have included
appropriate footnotes to the relevant financial tables as a reminder that each such financial information
may be affected by accounting errors. Investors should therefore exercise caution when comparing our
results of operations and balance sheet assets among the periods under review in this Offering
Memorandum, and in particular those relating to our Finance industry vertical.

Following the identification of the accounting errors described above, we have implemented what we
believe to be adequate changes to reinforce our internal control systems as well as oversight mechanisms
to prevent the implementation of similar accounting errors. The measures we deployed include: (i) an
intensified monitoring of our invoice cycle, (ii) the enhanced supervision of sales functions at each
industry vertical, (iii) the implementation of a new credit monitoring procedure, and (iv) the
centralization of internal control and risk functions previously performed by each industry vertical
independently. We also created a new “order management” function and strengthened our internal
control team, including by appointing a new credit manager.

**Our Industry Verticals, Activities and Technologies**

We report our results across six industry verticals in accordance with IFRS 8 (Operating Segments) as
follows: (i) Finance, (ii) Health, (iii) Industry & Services, (iv) Telco & Media, (v) Energy & Utilities,
and (vi) Public Administration.

Our Finance industry vertical comprises services to banks, insurance companies and financial
institutions. Through our Health industry vertical, we serve public and private entities operating in the
healthcare sector. Through our Industry & Services industry vertical we serve large and medium-sized
corporations operating in various industries, including the retail, fashion, manufacturing, and process
agriculture industries, as well as public and private operators in the transportation sector. Our Telco &
Media industry vertical comprises services to customers in the telecommunications industry as well as
media services. Our Energy & Utilities industry vertical comprises services to customers in the energy
industry as well as utilities. Lastly, through our Public Administration industry vertical we serve central
and local public administration customers.

We believe that the organization and reporting of the results of our business along these industry
verticals properly reflects the positioning of our business across our key industries and provides
investors with a detailed understanding of the nature of our customers and the industries that drive our
results of operations. Please refer to “Summary—Summary Historical and Certain Other Financial
_Data,” “Business—Our Business—Industry Verticals” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of_
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations” for a presentation of our revenues and Adjusted_
EBITDA by industry vertical for each of the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022.
Additionally, the period-to-period discussion of our results of operations set forth under “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” includes a discussion of_
our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA split by industry vertical. Following a strategic review of our
business operations and positioning, beginning on January 1, 2022, we also report our results by the
following activity types through which we offer our IT services, software and digital platforms to our
customers: Proprietary Solutions, Digitech and System Integration. This Offering Memorandum
presents and discusses our results for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021 by retrospectively
grouping our results by activity types even if implemented beginning on January 1, 2022. Previously,
until December 31, 2021, we reported our results by the following activity types: Proprietary Solutions,
Application Transformation and Managed Services. Compared to our former activities split, our
Proprietary Solutions portfolio has remained substantially unchanged (the main difference being the
impact of the spin-off of our subsidiary OverIT in 2021) and encompasses all solutions embedding
software products for which we retain exclusive ownership (regardless of whether such solutions related
to high-technological or traditional products), while our previous allocation of services and products
between Application Transformation and Managed Services has been further refined to reflect our new
strategy in targeting customers by well-defined activity types, in order to achieve competitive
advantages. In particular, through our new Digitech activities we aim to consolidate our entire portfolio


-----

of professional IT solutions for high-technology third-party products into a comprehensive hub. In
addition, our Digitech activities include day-to-day management services and end-to-end operation
services for the infrastructure of our customers (which also comprise hosting and desktop management
solutions). Following the acquisition of Atlantic Technologies in 2022, we offer its services as part of
our Digitech portfolio. Moreover, through our new System Integration activities we aim to focus on
offering solutions for the management and maintenance of more traditional IT systems, thereby
enhancing our support capabilities. Moreover, following the completion of the Be Acquisition, we offer
a large portion of Be’s products and solutions portfolio (mainly comprised of Be’s business consulting,
information technology and digital business services) through a new fourth separate activity type,
Consulting, while the remaining portion of Be’s portfolio has been allocated to, and is offered as part
of, our existing three activity types. We expect that the allocation of Be’s products and solutions
portfolio by activity types will evolve as the integration of Be into our business operations progresses.

Our activities related to Proprietary Solutions cover a wide range of industry-specific, innovative
vertical software as well as professional services directly related to such software. Typically, our
Proprietary Solutions relate to software products for which we retain exclusive ownership and which
we make available to our customers on the basis of individually negotiated licensing agreements. Our
activities relating to Digitech include the development and customization of high-growth digital
enabling solutions using advanced analytics, cloud, cybersecurity, customer experience, IoT, robotic
process automation, AR / MR / VR, digital twin and blockchain technologies in cooperation with our
partners including, among others, Microsoft, Google, Amazon, SAS, IBM and Oracle. In addition,
Digitech includes activities related to strategic partnerships with major software vendors including,
among others, Salesforce and SAP. Our System Integration activities comprise integration services
related to the implementation, management and maintenance of traditional IT solutions. Our Consulting
activities will comprise the business consulting, information technology and digital business services
offered by the Be Group. See “Business—Our Business—Activities.” Please refer to “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting_
_Results of Operations and Financial Condition—Sales Mix across Activities and Industry Verticals” for_
a presentation of our revenues by activity type.

indebtedness would have been had the Offering and the Bridge Facility Refinancing occurred on
December 31, 2022, nor does it purport to project our indebtedness, cash position or interest expense at
any future date. The as adjusted financial information has not been prepared in accordance with the

**Non-IFRS Measures**

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial measures that are not recognized by IFRS
or any other generally accepted accounting principles. We refer to these measures as “non-IFRS
measures” as they exclude amounts that are included in, or include amounts that are excluded from, the
most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS, or are calculated
using financial measures that are not calculated in accordance with IFRS. In particular, we present
certain financial measures of the Group and ratios related thereto in this Offering Memorandum,
including: organic revenue growth, organic Adjusted EBITDA growth, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA
Margin, capital expenditure, net working capital, adjusted net working capital, free operating cash flow
and cash conversion and other measures and ratios that are not recognized by, or presented in
accordance with, IFRS (collectively, the “Non-IFRS Measures”). We use such measures to assess the
financial performance and liquidity of our business. We believe that these and similar measures are
used widely by the investment community, securities analysts and other interested parties, as
supplemental measures of performance and liquidity and are intended to assist in the analysis of our
results of operations, profitability and ability to service debt.

Non-IFRS measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures used by other companies
and have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for
analysis of the Group’s operating results as reported under IFRS.

An explanation of the relevance of each of the Non-IFRS measures, a reconciliation of the Non-IFRS
measures to the most directly comparable measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS
and a discussion of their limitations is set out in this Offering Memorandum. See “Summary Historical
_and Certain Other Financial Data.” We do not regard these non-IFRS measures as a substitute for, or_
superior to, the equivalent measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS or those
calculated using financial measures that are calculated in accordance with IFRS.

Our primary Non-IFRS Measures are defined as follows:

- “Organic revenue growth” and “Organic Adjusted EBITDA growth” are defined as the
percentage growth in Group revenue or Adjusted EBITDA, as applicable, between two periods


-----

(the later of such periods, the “subsequent period”), excluding from the subsequent period the
contribution to the Group’s revenues or Adjusted EBITDA, as applicable, by entities that were
acquired by the Group during such period;

- “Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as net profit from continuing operations before income taxes,
income (expenses) from investments, financial income, financial expense (excluding interests
on lease liabilities), interest on lease liabilities, depreciation of right-of-use assets, depreciation
of property, plant and equipment, amortization of intangible assets, impairment of assets, and
further adjusted for the effects of certain events and transactions that management considers to
be unrelated to our underlying trading performance, including stock option costs, retirement
incentives, audit costs, non-ordinary charges related to the OverIT spin-off, charges for
corporate transactions, non-income tax assessment costs and corporate strategic assessment
expenses. We present Adjusted EBITDA because it is widely used by securities analysts,
investors and other interested parties to evaluate the profitability of companies. Adjusted
EBITDA eliminates potential differences in performance caused by variations in capital
structures (affecting net finance costs), tax positions (such as the availability of net operating
losses against which to relieve taxable profits), the cost and age of tangible assets (affecting
relative depreciation expense), the extent to which intangible assets are identifiable (affecting
relative amortization expense) and other items not considered by management to relate to the
Group’s underlying operations;

- “Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA _divided by total revenues,_
expressed as a percentage;

- “Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended
December 31, 2022, as further adjusted to include (i) the Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended
December 31, 2022 of certain companies acquired in 2022 to the extent not already reflected in
the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2022, based on the respective
financial statements and/or management accounts of such entities, (ii) the expected run rate
impact from certain cost saving measures that we started implementing in 2022 and that we
expect to fully realize by the end of 2023 as if such measures had been fully implemented on
January 1, 2022, based on management’s assumptions regarding the impact of such measures,
in each case, as if such acquisitions had been completed, and such initiatives and measures had
been fully implemented, as of January 1, 2022, (iii) the Adjusted EBITDA of Be for the year
ended December 31, 2022 to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA
for the year ended December 31, 2022, based on its financial statements presented in
accordance with IFRS, as if Be had been fully consolidated in our financial statements on
January 1, 2022, and (iv) the estimated effect on our results of certain cost savings that we
expect to generate following completion of the Be Acquisition, through cost savings synergies
from the integration of the Be Group into our business that we expect to fully realize by the end
of 2024 as if Be had been fully consolidated in our financial statements from, and such measures
had been fully implemented on, January 1, 2022, based on management’s assumptions
regarding the impact of such synergies, in each case, as if the Be Acquisition had been
completed, and such initiatives, measures and cost savings synergies had been fully
implemented, as of January 1, 2022. Neither our independent auditors, nor any other
independent accountants, have compiled, examined, or performed any procedures with respect
to the presentation of Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA contained herein, nor have they
expressed any opinion or any other form of assurance on such information or its achievability,
and assume no responsibility for, and disclaim any association with, such presentation.

- “Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted
EBITDA divided by the sum of aggregated revenues of the Group as if the Be Acquisition and
the acquisition by the Group of certain other companies completed in 2022 had occurred on
January 1, 2022, expressed as a percentage;


-----

- “Capital expenditure” is defined as purchase of property, plant and equipment plus purchase of
intangible assets. Capital expenditure excludes the consideration paid by us for the acquisition
of other businesses;

- “Net Working Capital” is defined as current customer contract assets, inventories, deferred
contract costs, trade receivables and other current assets less current trade payables, other
current liabilities, current tax payables and current provisions for risks and charges;

- “Adjusted net working capital” is defined as Net working capital, as adjusted for certain effects
that management does not consider representative of the ongoing operations of the Group;

- “Free operating cash flow” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital expenditure less change
in Adjusted net working capital less IFRS 16 depreciation;

- “Pro Forma free cash flow” is defined as Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA less Capital
expenditure;

- “Cash conversion” is defined as (x) Adjusted EBITDA less Capital expenditure divided by (y)
Adjusted EBITDA, expressed as a percentage; and

- “Pro Forma cash conversion” is defined as Pro Forma free cash flow divided by Pro Forma Run
Rate Adjusted EBITDA, expressed as a percentage.

The Non-IFRS Measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS
and should not be considered as alternatives to performance or liquidity measures derived in accordance
with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. An explanation of the relevance of
each of the Non-IFRS Measures, a reconciliation of the Non-IFRS Measures to the most directly
comparable measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS and a discussion of their
limitations is set out in this Offering Memorandum under “Summary Historical and Certain Other
_Financial Data.”_

The Non-IFRS Measures are not measures of financial performance recognized under IFRS and they
should not be considered as alternatives to net income (loss) as measures of operating performance,
operating cash flows, the basis for dividend distribution or as measures of liquidity. Consequently, the
methodology used for their calculation may not be consistent with that adopted by other companies and,
therefore, the Non-IFRS Measures we present herein may not be comparable with those of others. Some
of the limitations of Non-IFRS Measures are that:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or
contractual commitments;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the significant interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service
interest or principal payments on our debt;

- they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our
consolidated income statement;

- they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider
not to be indicative of our ongoing operations;

- assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be
replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such
replacements; and


-----

- other companies in our industry and analysts may calculate these measures differently than we
do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, the Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of
discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will
be available to us to meet our obligations or as measures of performance in order to assist in the analysis
of our operating results and profitability. You should compensate for these limitations by relying
primarily on our 2022 Audited Financial Statements and using these Non-IFRS Measures only as a
supplement to evaluate our performance. Please see “Summary Historical and Certain Other Financial
_Data,” “Selected Historical Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of_
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the 2022 Audited Financial Statements (including_
the related notes), included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Certain key performance indicators and other non-financial operating data included in this Offering
Memorandum are derived from management estimates, are not part of our 2022 Audited Financial
Statements or our accounting records, and have not been audited or otherwise reviewed by outside
auditors, consultants or experts. Our use or computation of these measures may not be comparable to
the use or computation of similarly titled measures reported by other companies. Any or all of these
measures should not be considered in isolation or as an alternative measure of performance under IFRS.

**Rounding**

Certain numerical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial data presented in
millions or in thousands, have been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the
data in this Offering Memorandum may vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such
information. In addition, as a result of such rounding, the totals of certain financial information
presented in tabular form may differ from the information that would have appeared in such totals using

**Overview**

We are a leading specialist provider of IT services, software and digital solutions in Italy, with a market
share of approximately 13% in Application & Infrastructure Implementation and 8% in Application
Managed Services, ranking first in three of the five industry verticals under Implementation services in
which we operate, in each case calculated in terms revenue (constant currency basis), in 2022, according
to Gartner® research (Gartner Inc., Market Share: IT Services Worldwide 2022, April 2023). We
provide a holistic suite of leading software and digital solutions to more than 2,750 customers, including
companies and public administration entities, and focus on supporting our customers in digital
transformation projects through a portfolio of integrated ICT solutions, products and consultancy
services. We couple new and advanced digital enabling capabilities, including artificial intelligence
(“AI”) and advanced analytics, cloud-based services, cybersecurity, customer experience, IoT, robotic
process automation, AR / MR / VR, blockchain and digital twin platforms, with a strong know-how of
traditional technological solutions and an intimate knowledge of our broad client base’s core processes.
For the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenues of €1,422.6 million and Adjusted
EBITDA of €207.8 million (representing an Adjusted EBITDA Margin of 14.6%). In addition,
following settlement of the Mandatory Offer on December 22, 2022 and completion of the SqueezeOut on December 28, 2022, we successfully completed the Be Acquisition, and as of the date of this
Offering Memorandum, we wholly own the Be Group. The Be Group is one of the leading Italian
players in the IT consulting sector and provider of business consulting, information technology and
digital business services to major financial and insurance institutions in Europe, including Italy. The Be
Group also showcases distinctive capabilities in specialized areas such as services for corporate
investment banking and capital markets (including process design solutions, back-office systems, and
capital markets accounting and brokerage platforms), as well as the payments sector (including card
based products, value-added services and open banking models, as well as services for payment systems
and schemes). After giving effect to the Be Acquisition and the acquisition by the Group of certain other
companies completed in 2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s results) as if they had
occurred on January 1, 2022, we estimate that the aggregated revenues of the Group for the year ended
December 31, 2022 would have been €1,636.8 million. In addition, after adjusting our Adjusted
EBITDA to include the Adjusted EBITDA of the Be Group and the Adjusted EBITDA of certain
companies acquired in 2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA for
the year ended December 31, 2022), the expected run rate impact from certain ongoing cost saving
activities that we started implementing in 2022, and the impact of certain cost savings synergies
expected to be generated from the integration of the Be Group into our business, in each case, as if such
acquisitions were completed, and such initiatives, actions and cost savings synergies were fully
implemented, as of January 1, 2022, we estimate that our Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA for
the year ended December 31, 2022 would have been €256.9 million.

We operate in the attractive and growing Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets which
proved resilient against the COVID-19 pandemic and, according to Anitec-Assinform, grew at a CAGR
of approximately 4.4% between 2019 and 2021. In 2021, these markets were worth approximately €21.8
billion. The Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets benefit from strong ongoing
digitalization across the Italian public and private sectors and increasing spending in transformation
projects from traditional IT to new digital enabling technologies, which further increased underpinned
by the 2021 National Recovery and Resilience Plan (“PNRR”) adopted by the Italian government in
response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Our leading position in the Italian ICT Services and Software &
Solutions markets, which has been further consolidated following the successful completion of the Be
Acquisition, coupled with our deep local and regional market knowledge and long-lasting relationships
with our customers and partners, uniquely positions us to capitalize on the strong growth in demand for
IT transformation services in Italy, which is expected to grow at a CAGR of 8.4% between 2021 and
2025, according to Anitec-Assinform.

We offer our IT services, software and digital platforms and solutions to our customers by engaging in
four distinct activity types: Proprietary Solutions, Digitech, System Integration and Consulting:


-----

- **Proprietary Solutions: We offer a wide range of cutting-edge customized, end-to-end IT**
services such as industry-specific, innovative vertical software and related services, primarily
to customers in our Finance, Energy & Utilities, Public Administration, Telco & Media and
Health industry verticals. Our Proprietary Solutions relate to four main software suites, and a
longer tail of approximately 20 smaller products, all developed in-house and owned by us. Our
Proprietary Solutions comprise end-to-end service partnerships with certain of our customers
through which we provide tailored digital service packages which also include System
Integration services. We estimate that, in 2021, we were one of the leading providers of
governance, risk and compliance reporting software for financial institutions, CRM solutions
and billing platforms for utilities providers and healthcare ERP solutions for hospitals in Italy
based on revenue. We generated 26.6% of our revenues in the year ended December 31, 2022
from our activities related to Proprietary Solutions. Following the Be Acquisition, we have
integrated a portion of Be Group’s products and solutions into our Proprietary Solutions
portfolio (including, among others, Be Group’s proprietary digital platforms). After giving
effect to the Be Acquisition and the acquisition by the Group of certain other companies
completed in 2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s results) as if they had
occurred on January 1, 2022, we estimate for the year ended December 31, 2022 we would
have generated 24% of the aggregated revenues of the Group from activities related to
Proprietary Solutions.

- **Digitech: We develop and customize high-growth, state-of-the-art digital enabling solutions**
for third-party software, and, in particular, using advanced analytics, cloud, cybersecurity,
customer experience, IoT, robotic process automation, AR / MR / VR, digital twin and
blockchain technologies in cooperation with our partners, including, among others, Microsoft,
Google, Amazon, SAS, IBM and Oracle. In addition, we are also a leading service provider and
system integrator in Italy, customizing and developing third-party digital-enabled IT solutions
through strategic partnerships with major software providers such as Salesforce and SAP. We
provide our Digitech activities on the basis of software and other technological products that
are non-proprietary, with the aim of offering highly customized solutions capable of being
integrated with both third-party and client-owned applications. In addition, as part of our
Digitech portfolio we support, maintain and update third party applications and offer projectbased system integration services for customers as well as software providers. Following the
acquisition of Atlantic Technologies, an international ICT consultancy firm with three offices
worldwide and more than 200 specialized and certified professionals, in 2022, we offer its
services as part of our Digitech portfolio. We generated 36.0% of our revenues in the year ended
December 31, 2022, from our activities related to Digitech. Following the successful
completion of the Be Acquisition, we have integrated a portion of Be Group’s solutions into
our Digitech portfolio (including, among others, certain of Be Group’s ICT solutions). After
giving effect to the Be Acquisition and the acquisition by the Group of certain other companies
completed in 2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s results) as if they had
occurred on January 1, 2022, we estimate for the year ended December 31, 2022 we would
have generated 33% of the aggregated revenues of the Group from activities related to Digitech.

- **System Integration: Our System Integration services comprise integration services related to**
the implementation, managing and maintenance of traditional IT solutions, as well as day-today management and operation services of our customer’ end-to-end infrastructure, including
hosting and desktop management. In addition, our System Integration portfolio comprises other
specialized services we offer to our customers, such as complex information systems,
customized system architectures and applications integration services (for new or existing
hardware and software). Our System Integration portfolio is also supported by our strong knowhow legacy. We generated 32.4% of our revenues in the year ended December 31, 2022 from
our activities related to System Integration solutions. Following the successful completion of
the Be Acquisition, we have integrated a portion of Be Group’s solutions into our System
Integration portfolio (including, among others, the activities of Be’s subsidiary Be Digitech
Solutions S.p.A.). After giving effect to the Be Acquisition and the acquisition by the Group of


-----

certain other companies completed in 2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s
results) as if they had occurred on January 1, 2022, we estimate for the year ended December
31, 2022, we would have generated 28% of the aggregated revenues of the Group from activities
related to System Integration.

- **Consulting: Our Consulting activities comprise the business consulting, information**
technology and digital business services offered by the Be Group, mainly to major financial
and insurance institutions in Europe, including Italy. We generated 5.0% of our revenues in the
year ended December 31, 2022 from our activities related to Consulting, representing the
portion of Be’s revenues relating to business consulting, information technology and digital
business services for the period from its consolidation into our results (i.e., September 26, 2022)
until December 31, 2022. After giving effect to the Be Acquisition and the acquisition by the
Group of certain other companies completed in 2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the
Group’s results) as if they had occurred on January 1, 2022, we estimate for the year ended
December 31, 2022, we would have generated 14% of the aggregated revenues of the Group
from activities related to Consulting.

We operate in Italy as well as in 20 countries worldwide including major European countries (such as
Belgium, France, Germany, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom), the United States and Latin
American countries, such as Brazil. For the year ended December 31, 2022, revenues generated from
customers outside of Italy accounted for 18.3% of our total revenues. Moreover, following the
completion of the Be Acquisition, we strengthened our international operations, as we offer Be Group’s
products and services in three additional new countries (Poland, Romania and Albania), and increased
our presence in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. After giving effect to the Be Acquisition and the
acquisition by the Group of certain other companies completed in 2022 (to the extent not already
reflected in the Group’s results) as if they had occurred on January 1, 2022, we estimate that
approximately 21% of aggregated revenues of the Group would have been generated outside of Italy
for the year ended December 31, 2022. In Italy, we are present in all regions and most metropolitan
cities (including Milan, Rome and Turin) and operate across several sectors of the economy, including
public administration, financial services, utilities, telecommunications, transportation, infrastructure
and healthcare. In particular, we operate our activity types with industry-specific process knowledge
across six industry verticals, which correspond to our reporting segments under IFRS 8 (Operating
_Segments) and represent the verticals or strategic markets in which we operate, with industry-specific_
knowledge supported technologies and competences. Our six industry verticals are Finance, Health,
Industry & Services, Telco & Media, Energy & Utilities and Public Administration. In addition, for
internal reporting purposes, in 2022 we implemented a strategic initiative focusing on the consolidation
of our Energy & Utilities, Industry & Services and Telco & Media industry verticals into a new business
unit, “Enterprise,” and, in 2023, of our Health and Public Administration industry verticals into our new
“Public Sector” business unit. We believe that our new “Enterprise” business unit will increase our
ability to effectively respond to our customers’ needs, with the aim to deliver high-performing solutions
and strengthen our role in rapidly evolving markets. In particular, we believe that through “Enterprise”
we will increase the coordination between our industry verticals, while unlocking the ability to develop
high-quality digital systems for the delivery of cross-domain solutions.

We have historically been able to achieve long-lasting, integral customer relationships by creating
significantly customized and highly specialized products and services that we integrate into our endcustomers’ IT systems. Our average relationship tenure with customers is approximately ten years. Our
business benefits from low customer concentration and significant customer diversification across all
of our industry verticals, with no customer accounting for more than 6.0% of our revenues and no
industry vertical accounting for more than 26.4% of our revenues for the year ended December 31,
2022. In the same period, our top ten customers generated 30% of our revenues.

We believe our success and leading position in the Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions
markets is largely dependent on our strong focus on R&D, and we invested approximately €25 million
in R&D in the year ended December 31, 2022. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are
involved in more than 100 research projects, and our R&D Lab department relies on a team of over 500
professionals, which includes researchers and data scientists (both directly part of our R&D Lab
department) and employees in our Development Labs, Competence Centers and Products Labs, who
cooperate closely with our R&D Labs.

We believe that the Be Acquisition enabled us to create a strong industrial combination and to further
consolidate our strong position in the markets served by our Finance industry vertical as well as our
end-to-end capabilities, given Be Group’s large addressable market, underpinned by strong underlying
market trends. Following the completion of the Be Acquisition, we believe we have further increased
potential cross-selling opportunities, by leveraging both our and Be Group’s brand recognition and
strong reputation across our wide platform of customers, while coupling our broad offer of IT services,
software and digital platforms and solutions with top tier consulting services. For example, we have
been deploying an end-to-end platform of solutions aiming to address all of our customers’ IT needs,


-----

by covering the design of their IT architecture as well as the implementation and integration of
proprietary solutions and/or third-party solutions into their systems. Moreover, following completion
of the Be Acquisition, our customer base includes Be Group’s customers, which comprise major
financial and insurance institutions, such as UniCredit, Nexi, MasterCard and Poste Italiane S.p.A.,
along with Italian industrial players, some of which are already customers of the Group. After giving
effect to the Be Acquisition and the acquisition by the Group of certain other companies completed in
2022 (to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s results) as if they had occurred on January 1,
2022, we estimate that the Be Group would have comprised approximately 16% of the aggregated
revenues of the Group for the year ended December 31, 2022.

**Our Strengths**

**_Leading player in the attractive Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets with strong_**
**_growth driven by digital transformation secular trend_**

The Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets grew at a CAGR of approximately 4.4%
between 2019 and 2021, and were worth approximately €21.8 billion in 2021. In addition, the Italian
ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets are forecast to grow at a CAGR of 8.4% between 2021
and 2025, mainly driven by (i) increasing penetration of the Italian ICT Services and Software &
Solutions markets, which has further accelerated as a result of the growing reliance on remote working
as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, (ii) digitalization across all private and public clients, and
increasing spending in transformation projects from traditional IT to new digital enabling technologies
and (iii) increasingly mission critical nature of IT services spending.

The Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets have historically been, and remain,
underpenetrated compared to certain equivalent markets in other European countries, according to
management estimates, which we believe provides us with opportunities for significant further growth,
including in connection with the implementation by the Italian government and regulators of policies
that favor digitalization through IT investments, such as the Industry 4.0 plan and the PNRR,
particularly with respect to its “Mission 1”, which allocates a budget of approximately €30 billion to
investments in digitalization, innovation, competitiveness, culture and tourism, and its “Mission 6”,
which allocates a budget of approximately €11 billion to investments in innovation, research and
digitalization of the national healthcare system. These policies are aimed at increasing the penetration
of IT services in Italy and supporting the digital transition in the country, with expected additional
information and communication technology investments, particularly in the areas of connectivity,
digital transition and enhanced digitalization. The following chart shows a breakdown of the PNRR’s
expected investments across its six missions by the end of 2026, along with an overview of certain key
initiatives addressable by the Group included under its “Mission 1” and “Mission 6:”

We believe that our strategic positioning and clear focus on innovation and digital transformation
represents a naturally close match to the objectives of PNRR’s “Mission 1” and “Mission 6.” Growth
in the Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets is mainly driven by strong ongoing
digitalization across the Italian public and private sectors, with increased IT services spending on and
diversified growth of new digital enabling technologies, such as (i) IoT (which is expected to grow by
approximately 8.8% between 2022 and 2025), (ii) cloud (which is expected to grow by approximately
24.5% between 2022 and 2025), (iii) big data (which is expected to grow by approximately 12.7%
between 2022 and 2025), (iv) cyber security (which is expected to grow by approximately 14.0%
between 2022 and 2025), (v) AI (which is expected to grow by approximately 21.7% between 2022 and
2025 and (vi) blockchain (which is expected to grow by approximately 26.5% between 2022 and 2025),
according to Anitec-Assinform. See “Industry and Market Overview.”

Additionally, growth in IT services spend is also driven by the increasingly mission-critical nature of
IT services in business operations, which we expect to result in IT services spend in Italy becoming
more resilient in the face of future market downturns and less correlated to macroeconomic trends. We
are also seeing an increasing focus on cost efficiency and specialization of IT services, which is leading
companies to rely on external providers rather than developing IT in-house. For example, we have
recently been awarded a multi-vendor tender by CONSIP relating the provision of IT cloud services to
certain Italian public administrations, aimed at driving a migration from on-premises IT services to
cloud. We believe that our size and expertise in complex software, solutions and IT services compared
to some of our smaller competitors and competitors focusing on less complex products and services,
position us well to benefit from such trends, which we expect to be confirmed in the mid- to long term
and that digitalization will increase and accelerate, including as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. In
addition, we believe that our combination with the Be Group enhances our positioning and our ability
to capitalize from increased IT investments by both the Italian government and the private sector.

**_Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets have strong protected local characteristics,_**
**_which advantages local players like us and creates significant barriers to entry for international_**
**_players_**

The Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets are characterized by high barriers to entry,
especially with respect to international competitors, mainly due to cultural and local commercial
complexities, such as language, local regulatory constraints in most markets including banking, energy,
and healthcare, the importance of local relationships and proximity to customers. As a result, we believe
that these barriers favor local players, thus allowing us to capitalize on our leading positioning in the
market for both traditional technologies and digital enabling technologies in Italy, given our deep
knowledge of the domestic market and long-lasting relationships with a wide cross-section of Italian
customers and partners. Italian customers have also shown to prefer software and IT services suppliers
with whom they share a common language, that have extensive operations in Italy and that have an indepth know-how of the applicable Italian legal and regulatory framework, which we believe makes
entering the Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets more challenging for international
players.

**_Leading ICT Services and Software & Solutions provider in Italy with strong positions across all_**
**_industry verticals supported by deep technology expertise, strong business process knowledge and_**
**_well-established customer relationships_**

We are a leading ICT Services and Software & Solutions provider in Italy. In 2022, we were the largest
provider of Application & Infrastructure Implementation services in Italy, with a market share of
approximately 13% in terms of revenues compared to the market shares of approximately 11% and 8%
of our two closest competitors, Accenture and Reply, respectively, according to Gartner. Additionally,
in 2022, we were also one of the largest providers of Application Managed Services in Italy, with a
market share of approximately 8% in terms of revenue, compared to the market shares of approximately
24% and approximately 9% of Accenture and Reply, respectively, according to Gartner (see chart
below). We are one of the largest local players in a fragmented market where scale increasingly matters,
and we have a consistent history of market share gain. The addition of the Be Group into our business
has further consolidated this position, particularly in the markets served by our Finance industry
vertical. We believe that the Be Group is a strong player with unique and distinctive capabilities,
extending to both core areas (such as payments and CIB/capital markets), as well as emerging areas of
focus (such as data, analytics, cyber and insurance). The Be Group also provides highly defensible
consulting activities through a combination of proprietary solutions software, digital projects and endto-end vertical projects, which we expect will enable us to expand the breadth of our solutions portfolio
and enrich our Proprietary Solutions and Digitech offerings, while also allowing us to operate through
our new Consulting activities portfolio. We believe that due to a trend among our customers to
consolidate around key partners, large IT service providers such as ourselves are able to absorb a large
portion of IT spend from returning customers.

We hold leading positions across our industry verticals, which are underpinned by our broad offering
of technology solutions, local and regional regulatory knowledge, long-standing relationship with our
customers and partners, reputation for reliable delivery and cost competitiveness. The following table
