(a) These capital expenditure figures are audited.

(1) We define organic revenue growth as the percentage growth in Group revenue between two periods (the later of such

periods, the “subsequent period”), excluding from the subsequent period the contribution to the Group’s revenue by
entities that were acquired by the Group during such period. Organic revenue growth is not a measure presented in
accordance with IFRS. When assessing our operating performance, you should not consider this data in isolation or as a
substitute for our revenue growth that is calculated in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other
_Information—Non-IFRS Measures.” If we excluded revenues generated in the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022_
in our Finance industry vertical, which recorded a lower performance in 2022 also as a result of the impact from the
accounting errors described under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Accounting Errors,” our 2022
organic revenue growth would have been 10.0%. Furthermore, if from such organic revenue growth we also excluded


-----

revenues generated by Movilitas, which we acquired at the end of 2021, from our revenues for the year ended December
31, 2022, our 2022 organic revenue growth would have been 5.6%.

(2) We define Adjusted EBITDA as net profit from continuing operations before income taxes, income (expenses) from

investments, financial income, financial expense (excluding interests on lease liabilities), interest on lease liabilities,
depreciation of right-of-use assets, depreciation of property, plant and equipment, amortization of intangible assets,
impairment of assets, and further adjusted for the effects of certain events and transactions that management considers to
be unrelated to our underlying trading performance, including stock option costs, retirement incentives, audit costs, nonordinary charges related to the OverIT spin-off, charges for corporate transactions, non-income tax assessment costs and
corporate strategic assessment expenses. We define Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA for the
year ended December 31, 2022, as further adjusted to include (i) the Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31,
2022 of certain companies acquired in 2022 to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA for the
year ended December 31, 2022, based on the respective financial statements and/or management accounts of such entities,
(ii) the expected run rate impact from certain cost saving measures that we started implementing in 2022 and that we
expect to fully realize by the end of 2023 as if such measures had been fully implemented on January 1, 2022, based on
management’s assumptions regarding the impact of such measures, (iii) the Adjusted EBITDA of Be for the year ended
December 31, 2022 to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31,
2022, based on its financial statements presented in accordance with IFRS, as if Be had been fully consolidated in our
financial statements on January 1, 2022, and (iv) the estimated effect on our results of certain cost savings that we expect
to generate following completion of the Be Acquisition through cost savings synergies from the integration of the Be
Group into our business that we expect to fully realize by the end of 2024 as if Be had been fully consolidated in our
financial statements from, and such measures had been fully implemented on, January 1, 2022, based on management’s
assumptions regarding the impact of such synergies, in each case, as if such acquisitions had been completed, and such
initiatives, measures and cost savings synergies had been fully implemented, as of January 1, 2022. Management believes
that adjustments relating to certain expenses and income were necessary in order to ensure a better comparability of the
historical data relating to the financial years in question as these include items not considered by management to be
attributable to the normal operational management of our business. We believe Adjusted EBITDA is a useful metric for
investors to understand our results of operations and profitability because it permits investors to evaluate our recurring
profitability from underlying operating activities. Additionally, we believe that Adjusted EBITDA provides investors
with a tool to compare the historical performance of our business across different periods as our adjustments to net profit
from continuing operations and the exclusion of certain costs and expenses include items not considered by management
to be attributable to the day-to-day operation of our business. We believe Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA is a
useful metric for investors to understand our results of operations and profitability because it gives pro forma effect to
the Be Acquisition and certain cost savings synergies which we expect to generate from the integration of the Be Group
into our business, in each case, as if they had been completed on January 1, 2022. We also use these measures internally
to establish forecasts, budgets and operational goals to manage and monitor our business, as well as evaluating our
underlying historical performance. Our presentation of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA
may be different from the presentation used by other companies and therefore comparability may be limited. Adjusted
EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA are Non-IFRS Measures and the terms Adjusted EBITDA and Pro
Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA are not defined under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles.
Consequently, the use of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA has certain limitations. Adjusted
EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA are not measures of net income, operating income, operating
performance or liquidity presented in accordance with IFRS. When assessing our operating performance, you should not
consider this data in isolation or as a substitute for our net income, operating income or any other operating performance
or liquidity measure that is calculated in accordance with IFRS. Neither our independent auditors, nor any other
independent accountants, have compiled, examined, or performed any procedures with respect to the presentation of, Pro
Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA contained herein, nor have they expressed any opinion or any other form of assurance
on such information or its achievability, and assume no responsibility for, and disclaim any association with, such
presentation. For a more detailed description of the limitations of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted
EBITDA as analytical tools, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Measures.” See also “Risk
_Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—We have made and may make acquisitions or enter into_
_transactions that may present risks, and we may not realize the financial and strategic goals that were contemplated at_
_the time of any transaction and, additionally, there are risks associated with the integration of any acquisitions,” “Risk_
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our cost saving measures may prove to be ineffective” and “Risk_
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We may not realize any or all of the adjustments to Pro Forma_
_Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA included in the Offering Memorandum.”_

(h) Represents the estimated run rate impact on our Adjusted EBITDA of certain cost savings initiatives that we have started

implementing in 2022 with the aim of further streamlining our operations and achieve annual run rate cost savings, which we expect
to realize fully by the end of 2023 (excluding €9.8 million of cost savings we already achieved for the year ended December 31, 2022
that are therefore not included in this adjustment), based on management’s assumptions regarding the impact of such actions in the
year ended December 31, 2022, as if such actions and initiatives had been fully implemented as of January 1, 2022, consisting of (in
aggregate, including both cost savings already achieved in 2022 and cost savings expected to be achieved in 2023) (A) procurement
initiatives, comprising: (i) €10.0 million of estimated run rate cost savings from the streamlining of our contractual relationships with
external IT consultants through the introduction of (x) competitive tender procedures, and (y) a structured supplier qualification
process, which we started implementing in the first and second quarter of 2022, respectively; (ii) €3.0 million of estimated run rate
cost savings from the reduction of costs related to the procurement of software products, primarily by consolidating our current
software providers base, and consolidating our IT spend with certain selected OEMs, which we started implementing in each case in
the second quarter of 2022 (€4.0 million of which have been already achieved as of December 31, 2022); (B) €1.6 million of estimated
run rate cost savings from optimization initiatives targeting the reduction of utilities, maintenance and rent costs related to our real
estate portfolio, including the reduction of our square footage at multiple locations and office closures in up to three out of 13 nonstrategic locations in Italy as well as the opening of a new Group flagship office in Milan (Italy), which we started implementing in
the second quarter of 2022 (€1.2 million of which have been already achieved as of December 31, 2022); and (C) €4.6 million of run
rate cost savings, all of which have been already achieved for the year ended December 31, 2022) from a broad range of other cost
saving initiatives, including the outsourcing of payroll activities, the implementation of headcount optimization and reduction projects
including nearshoring activities in Serbia and adjacent countries, rationalization projects aimed at consolidating our legal structure,
and vendor rebate management activities, which we started implementing in part in the first quarter of 2022. Once achieved, we
expect that these cost savings will structurally reduce the Group’s cost base going forward. We incurred approximately €2.5 million
of one-off costs in connection with the achievement of these cost savings, primarily related to the involvement of a third party supplier
with proven expertise in technology procurement and supply chain dynamics, and we expect to only incur further de minimis costs
for the achievement thereof. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties and may not give an accurate or complete
representation of the financial impact or results of these actions and initiatives for the period presented. The achievement of these
cost savings partly depends on factors that are outside of our control, including the renegotiation of certain contract terms with our
vendors, suppliers and business partners, and we may therefore be unable to implement some or all of such initiatives and/or generate
the expected benefits therefrom within the expected timeframe or at all. For a more detailed description of our cost saving initiatives
please see, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of
_Operations and Financial Condition—Our Cost Structure and Cost Saving Initiatives.” See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to_
_Our Business and Industry—Our cost saving measures may prove to be ineffective” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our_
_Business and Industry—We may not realize any or all of the adjustments to Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA included in the_
_Offering Memorandum” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—We have made and may make acquisitions_
_or enter into transactions that may present risks, and we may not realize the financial and strategic goals that were contemplated at_
_the time of any transaction and, additionally, there are risks associated with the integration of any acquisition.”_

(i) Represents the Adjusted EBITDA of Be for the year ended December 31, 2022, to the extent not already reflected in the Group’s

Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2022, as if Be had been fully consolidated into our results on January 1, 2022,
calculated on the basis of the financial statements of Be presented in accordance with IFRS and aligned to our own accounting policies
in order to ensure comparability with our key financial information. A large portion of Be Group’s revenues is generated from the
same subset of customers targeted by our Finance industry vertical, and certain solutions, consulting services or products currently
offered by the Be Group might overlap with products and solutions part of our Finance industry vertical portfolio. As a result,
combining our Adjusted EBITDA with Be’s Adjusted EBITDA may not provide a reliable indication of our combined results going
forward if sales of certain of Be Group’s products and solutions were to result in decreased sales generated from our Finance industry
vertical or vice versa. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We and the Be Group offer products and
_solutions which may compete with each other.” See also “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Financial Information_
_of Be” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We may not realize any or all of the adjustments to Pro_
_Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA included in the Offering Memorandum.”_

(j) Represents the estimated future impact on our Adjusted EBITDA from certain cost savings that we expect to generate following

completion of the Be Acquisition, through cost savings synergies from the integration of the Be Group into our business that we
expect to fully realize by the end of 2024, based on management’s assumptions, as if the relevant actions and initiatives had been
fully implemented as of January 1, 2022. Once achieved, we expect that these cost savings will structurally reduce the Group’s cost
base going forward. In connection with the achievement of these cost savings synergies, on the basis of management estimates, we
expect that we will incur one-off costs of approximately €5.0 million in 2023 and €10.0 million in 2024. We expect to realize these
cost savings through the following initiatives: (A) initiatives consisting of: (i) the optimization of our subcontractor and procurement
relationships, (ii) the optimization of external workforce utilization rates, and (iii) the deployment of near-shoring initiatives, (B) the
optimization and consolidation of the Group’s and Be’s combined real estate footprint and related costs including initiatives targeted


-----

at (i) the full consolidation of Be’s Rome offices into the Group’s Rome headquarters, (ii) the partial consolidation of Be’s current
Milan offices into the Group’s new flagship Milan office, and (iii) additional optimization initiatives to be implemented in further
locations with potential footprint overlaps, such as Turin and Vicenza, (C) the consolidation of the Group’s and Be’s staff and
administrative functions, and (D) the reduction of compliance expenses following the Delisting of the Be Group upon completion of
the Be Acquisition. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties and may not give an accurate or complete picture
of the financial impact or results of these actions and initiatives for the period presented. The achievement of these cost savings partly
depends on factors that are outside of our control, and we may be unable to implement some or all of such initiatives and/or generate
the expected benefits therefrom within the expected timeframe or at all. For a more detailed description of cost savings synergies that
we expect to generate from the integration of the Be Group into our business, please see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition—Our Cost Structure and_
_Cost Saving Initiatives.” See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our cost saving measures may prove_
_to be ineffective” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We may not realize any or all of the adjustments_
_to Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA included in the Offering Memorandum.”_

**Risks Related to Our Business and Industry**

**_The markets in which we operate are highly competitive._**

We operate in the Italian ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets, which represent our core
business and accounted for the vast majority of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022. We
operate in Italy as well as in 20 countries worldwide including major European countries (such as
Belgium, France, Germany, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom), the United States and Latin
American countries, such as Brazil. The markets in which we operate are highly competitive and subject
to rapid change. We believe that the principal competitive factors in these markets are service quality,
technical and industry expertise, price, innovation, established relationships with key customers, often
on a local level, knowledge of the regulatory framework, rapidity in providing services requested by
the customers and the ability to add value to a customer’s business. We compete for business with a
variety of players, including large multinational firms and local players that provide consulting,
technology and/ or business process services, in-house captives of potential customers, software
services companies that also provide business process services and accounting firms that also provide
IT consulting services. In addition, the trend toward international expansion by IT services providers
and continued technological changes may result in new and different competitors entering our markets.
These competitors may include entrants from other industries, such as the communications, software
and data networking industries or entrants from geographical locations with lower labor and production
costs than in Italy. Our main competitors include Italian and European players, such as Reply, Almaviva
and Capgemini and large American and global multinational companies such as IBM, Accenture, DXC
Technology and NTT Data. In the consulting space, our competitors include BIP, Deloitte, KPMG and
Accenture.

Some of our competitors may benefit from greater economies of scale, have greater financial,
marketing, technological or other resources, larger customer bases and better-established reputations
and customer relationships in our markets than we do. As a result, some of these competitors may be
able to:

- more efficiently or more rapidly develop superior services or solutions, gain greater market
acceptance and expand their service offerings;

- more quickly adapt to new or emerging technologies and changes in customer requirements;

- bundle services with other services they provide at reduced prices;

- adopt more aggressive pricing policies, including in response to cost increases such as those
driven by the surging inflationary environment prevailing since the first quarter of 2022, which
may include lower price increases than those implemented by us in order to avoid customer
attrition, which may in turn limit our ability to increase prices or force us to have to lower prices
for certain products or services to remain competitive in the market;

- devote greater financial, marketing and other resources to the research and development of their
services and solutions, thereby increasing their competitive pressure; and

- better withstand adverse market conditions.

Increased competition may also result in lower prices and volumes, higher costs for resources,
especially personnel, and, as a result, lower profitability. As a result, we may not be able to supply
customers with services that they deem superior at competitive prices and may lose market share to our
competitors. Any inability to face increased competition could have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operation, financial condition and prospects.


-----

**_We may incur liabilities, be restricted from participating in public tenders, suffer reputational_**
**_damage or be prosecuted for the actions of our directors, employees, agents, representatives, advisors_**
**_and intermediaries who engage in illegal activities, including under LD 231/2001._**

Conducting our business in an ethically acceptable manner is important to our reputation, status with
regulators and business prospects. Any contact by our directors, employees, agents or partners with the
public administration (including in the context of participating in tenders, interactions with the public
administration in the process of obtaining or renewing any authorization or license and any possible
public contribution) involves risks associated with fraud, bribery, corruption, incorrect use of public
contributions, inappropriate contact with or influence of public officials in connection with tenders and
other fraudulent or illegal activities by our employees and the cost and management distraction of
related investigations.

In particular, we are subject to Italian Legislative Decree 231/2001 (“LD 231/2001”), which is aimed,
_inter alia, at preventing direct or indirect acts of corruption (including between private individuals),_
bribery, money laundering, anti-competitive behavior, fraud, environmental crimes and other illegal
conduct (all such offences, as specifically defined in LD 231/2001).

Pursuant to LD 231/2001, we may be held responsible for certain crimes committed in Italy or abroad
including, among others, bribery, money laundering, corruption (including among private individuals),
fraud against the state, corporate offenses, market abuse, certain environmental violations, tender
rigging and workplace safety violations in our interest or for our benefit, by individuals having a
functional relationship with us at the time the relevant crime was committed, including third party
agents, partners or intermediaries, unless we were able to prove that such individuals fraudulently
violated such internal control model and it was for us impossible to avoid such violation. In such
circumstances, we may be subject to fines, confiscation of profits or legal sanctions (applied as interim
measures during the investigations), including, subject to certain conditions being met, provisional
measures, the termination of authorization, permits, licenses, concessions and financing arrangements,
including facilitated financing, suspension of our operations, or prohibitions on contracting with public
authorities. The duration of these disqualifications generally ranges from a minimum of three months
to a maximum of two years, although in very serious cases, some of these disqualifications can be
applied permanently. As an alternative to disqualification and suspension of operations, the court may
appoint a judicial custodian to run the company, with the consequence that the profits gained during the
receivership period are automatically confiscated. In addition, pursuant to Article 80 of Italian
Legislative Decree 50/2016, as amended (the “Italian Procurement Code”) as well as pursuant to new
provisions having similar content included in the new Italian procurement code recently approved by
the Italian Parliament and which will become effective on July 1, 2023 and will apply to new tenders,
public contracting authorities can exclude contractors from tender procedures, among other things, in
case they can demonstrate that such contractor has committed serious professional misconduct (grave
_illecito professionale) in Italy or abroad, which include criminal, civil and administrative offences, as_
well as instances in which a contractor did not provide specific information required by the relevant
contracting authority for tenders. If we were found to have committed any such serious professional
misconduct and/or failed to disclose specific information required for tenders, including actions or
events that could be deemed to constitute serious professional misconduct by the relevant authorities,
we could be excluded from participating in the relevant tenders, either automatically or following the
authorities’ assessment, for up to three years from when the relevant misconduct took place. We may
also be subject to allegations from competitors that we have failed to disclose specific information
required for tenders.

We are also subject to anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws and regulations in various jurisdictions in
which we operate, including the Italian Royal Decree 1398/1930 and LD 231/2001 and potentially the
U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the U.K. Bribery Act 2010, which, among other things, prohibit
giving or offering to give anything of value (such as gifts, payments or any other benefits) with the
intent to influence any officer, employee, agent or advisor or with the intent to award governmental
contract. Violations of such laws or adverse findings in proceedings related thereto, could result in


-----

penalties ranging from exclusion from tenders, to fines (which may be significant) and to other civil,
administrative or criminal sanctions.

Between 2020 and 2022, the Company, together with eight other companies and ATM, the company
wholly owned by the municipality of Milan (Comune di Milano) that manages the Milan metro system,
were subject to an investigation undertaken by authorities in Italy involving allegations that certain
public tenders involving ATM were impacted by improper benefits provided by employees of the
companies under investigation, including seven employees of the Company, including the head of the
Company’s transportation business sub-segment. In connection with the investigation, four of the
Company’s employees subject to the investigation were initially placed under house arrests and were
subsequently released following the pretrial hearings for the gathering of evidence before the beginning
of the criminal proceeding (incidente probatorio) that was held on November 4, 2020. In relation to
such events, the relevant authorities also investigated the Company as well as the other companies for
alleged violations of LD 231/2001, the Italian law on corporate liability for crimes, and in particular
corruption. In December 2021, the prosecutors announced the completion of the preliminary
investigation. On June 23, 2022, the prosecutors issued a request of indictment (rinvio a giudizio)
against certain employees subject to the investigation and separated the proceeding related to the
Company from the proceeding relating such employees pursuant to a separation decision
(provvedimento di stralcio). On November 9, 2022, the general public prosecutor endorsed the public
prosecutor’s decree to dismiss any case against the Company, thus confirming the dismissal of the
Company’s position. As a result, the Company is no longer involved in this criminal proceeding. The
negative effects of the investigation on the Company’s business and operations were limited. However,
on July 9, 2020, ATM terminated its two existing contracts with the Company and one existing contract
with its subsidiary, Engineering 365, which we estimate collectively accounted for approximately €0.7
million of revenues over the last three years. The Company has initiated legal proceedings challenging
the termination of such contracts by ATM claiming, among other things, that (i) ATM failed to carry
out the required evaluation or analysis confirming the Company’s alleged failure to carry out its
contractual obligations, (ii) the termination clause used by ATM to terminate the existing contracts was
not valid, (iii) the conduct of the Company’s employees subject to the ongoing investigation was not
the responsibility of the Company and (iv) ATM failed to take into account the self-cleansing actions
undertaken by the Company as well as the lack of a final judgment against the Company in this
investigation. In May 2022, ATM and the Company reached a final settlement in relation to such
proceedings, providing for the mutual dismissal of their respective claims.

Although we believe that we have adequate policies (including both the management and organizational
model we adopted pursuant LD 231/2001, which is aimed at preventing offences specifically identified
therein and the ISO 370001 anti-bribery management system) and enforcement mechanisms to ensure
legal and regulatory compliance with these and other similar laws and regulations, we cannot rule out
that some of our employees, subcontractors, agents or partners may violate any such legal and regulatory
requirements, which may expose us to criminal or civil investigations and enforcement actions,
including penalties and suspension or disqualification from procurement contracting. If we fail to
comply with legal and regulatory requirements, our business and reputation may be harmed. The
involvement or association of our directors, employees or agents in any fraud, bribery or corruption and
other crimes committed in relation to our activities or otherwise, or allegations or rumors relating
thereto, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations or negatively affect our reputation. The materialization of any of the foregoing risks could
have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_We may suffer legal civil or criminal sanctions if we are found to have violated IT-related laws or_**
**_rights or committed tortious acts related to IT._**

We are also exposed to the risk that our directors, employees or agents commit IT related crimes, which
may consist of using our infrastructure to violate the IT systems of our competitors, unlawful access to
banking data (including that of our customers) and damage the IT systems and documents. In addition,
we may be subject to claims in connection with accounting fraud, damage to property, business


-----

interruptions, unauthorized use of our property, unauthorized entry or breach of security protocols,
negligence, willful misconduct or other tortious acts by our employees or people who have gained
unauthorized access to premises operated by us through us. Such claims may be substantial and may
result in adverse publicity for us. Our business activities may also involve risks related to possible
accidents, which may be due to our employees’ activities or mistakes and may consist in crimes,
breaches of security measures, damages to third parties or manslaughter. The materialization of any of
the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial
condition and prospects.

**_We identified certain accounting errors relating to 2022 and previous fiscal years, which resulted in_**
**_an overstatement of the Company’s consolidated balance sheet assets and operating profits, and the_**
**_independent report to the 2022 Audited Financial Statements included in the Offering Memorandum_**
**_includes an emphasis of matter paragraph in relation to such errors due to our inability to allocate_**
**_their effects to periods prior to the year ended December 31, 2022. Investors should therefore exercise_**
**_caution when comparing our results of operations and balance sheet assets among the periods under_**
**_review in this Offering Memorandum, and in particular those relating to our Finance industry_**
**_vertical._**

In September 2022, we became aware of certain discrepancies between budgeted and final financial
data as of August 2022 relating to the Company’s Finance industry vertical and its subsidiary Nexen
(which is part of the Finance industry vertical). As a result of such discrepancies, we initiated a process,
with the assistance from external advisors, in order to verify the accounting methods used for specific
jobs within the Company’s Finance industry vertical and Nexen.

This verification process, which was completed at the end of the fiscal year 2022, identified certain
accounting errors relating to the 2022 and previous fiscal years, which resulted in an overstatement of
the Company’s consolidated balance sheet assets and operating profits. On this basis, management
determined that it was necessary to make certain corrections to the financial statements and applied IAS
8 (Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors), which governs, among other
things, how to recognise and represent errors, including those from previous years.

The verification process concluded that the accounting errors resulted from the allocation of costs in
our internal management system, which mainly led to the recognition of revenues:

(iii) relating to jobs that were not supported by any underlying contract, including by allocating to

such jobs costs that were unrelated to them (e.g., costs relating to other existing jobs), and by
recognizing corresponding revenues on our accounting systems; and

(iv) in advance of their accrual period.

As a result of such errors, the Company recorded non-recoverable balance sheet assets in the form of
invoices to be issued and work-in-progress (recognized in the financial statements under current assets
in the item “Customer contract assets”), which could not be and were not invoiced to customers.

Based on the results of the verification process, we quantified the following accounting effects:

(iii) an overstatement of the Group’s operating profit and EBITDA for the year ended December

31, 2022, of €10.9 million; and

(iv) an overstatement of the balance sheet assets as of January 1, 2022 of €46.0 million.

Both effects were corrected in our 2022 Audited Financial Statements.

While it was possible to allocate the effects of the accounting errors that occurred during 2022 to the
financial year ended December 31, 2022 due to the availability of current information on the progress


-----

of the Finance industry vertical’s contracts, we were not able to allocate with certainty the €46.0 million
overstatement of balance sheet assets as of January 1, 2022 to any prior periods because of the way our
management systems close out jobs and of the lack of traceability inside the system for such an
accounting error. As of the date of the Offering Memorandum, these accounting errors did not result in
a material impact on the relationship with our customers.

With respect to these accounting errors relating to fiscal years prior to 2022, we applied paragraphs 42
to 47 of IAS 8 as it was not possible to accurately and reasonably determine the impact of such errors
on such fiscal years. The Company therefore concluded that it was appropriate to adjust the opening
balance of assets and shareholders’ equity as of January 1, 2022, in order to reflect the lower value of
the assets of €46.0 million, by setting up a specific adjustment provision with the opening shareholders’
equity as of January 1, 2022, as a balancing entry.

As a result of these events, the independent auditors’ report for the consolidated financial statements of
the Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 included in this Offering Memorandum,
includes an emphasis of matter paragraph in relation to the inability of the Issuer to allocate the effects
of certain accounting errors described under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—
_Accounting Errors” to periods prior to the year ended December 31, 2022. See also Note 1.1 to our_
2022 Audited Financial Statements describing the correction of major errors under IAS 8.

With respect to the accounting treatment of the correction of errors relating to fiscal year 2022, these
were corrected prior to the approval of the 2022 Audited Financial Statements, as required by IAS 8
(par. 5), according to which “potential errors of the current financial year discovered in the same
_financial year shall be corrected before the publication of the financial statements is authorised.”_
Therefore, we corrected the relevant items in the income statement for the year ended December 31,
2022, generating a corresponding impact on the operating profit and EBITDA, which was rectified by
€10.9 million.

These accounting errors were the result of intentional misconduct by certain members of the
management of our Finance industry vertical. As of the date of the Offering Memorandum, such
members of management of the Finance industry vertical are being or have been replaced.

Following completion of the verification process carried out with respect to the Finance industry
vertical, we deemed it prudent to carry out further verification processes on all the other verticals of the
Company with the assistance of external advisors whose work was completed by the end of 2022. As
of the date of this Offering Memorandum, no incorrect accounting practices similar to those uncovered
in the Company’s Finance vertical and Nexen were identified. However, as a result of such verification
process, we prudentially made specific provisions of approximately €7.0 million (of which €6.1 million
relating to contract work in progress and €0.9 million to invoices to be issued) in our balance sheet as
of December 31, 2022, in respect of some positions relating to assets accrued mainly in previous years
and not invoiced, exclusively attributable to technical/commercial issues that emerged during the
execution of the jobs. Such €7.0 million provisions did not impact our consolidated EBITDA for the
year ended December 31, 2022.

As a result of the correction of the accounting errors in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements as
summarized above and the inability of the Issuer to quantify the above-mentioned corrections on net
income and shareholders’ equity for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, the consolidated
financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 contained in the 2022 Audited
Financial Statements included in the Offering Memorandum is not fully comparable with (i) the
financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Audited
Financial Statements and the 2021 Financial Statements, and (ii) the financial information as of and for
the year ended December 31, 2020 derived from the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements. Neither the
2021 Financial Statements nor the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements are included in the Offering
Memorandum. For the same reasons, the financial information as of and for the year ended December
31, 2020 derived from the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements is also not fully comparable with the


-----

financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Audited
Financial Statements and the 2021 Financial Statements.

This Offering Memorandum also includes certain financial information as of and for the two months
ended February 28, 2022 under “Summary—Recent Trading,” which is compared to corresponding
financial information as of and for the two months ended February 28, 2023. Such information as of
and for the two months ended February 28, 2022 was impacted by the accounting error described above
due to our inability to allocate the impact of the accounting error on the 2022 Audited Financial
Statements on a quarter or monthly basis through the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022. As a result,
the financial information as of and for the two months ended February 28, 2022 presented herein is not
fully comparable with the financial information as of and for the two months ended February 28, 2023
(which was not impacted by the accounting error), and therefore you should not place undue reliance
on such information.

As a consequence of the foregoing, throughout this Offering Memorandum, we have either marked any
such financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, including any
related averages, ranges and growth rates, with an asterisk (“*”) or we have included appropriate
footnotes to the relevant financial tables as a reminder that each such financial information may be
affected by accounting errors. Investors should therefore exercise caution when comparing our results
of operations and balance sheet assets among the periods under review in this Offering Memorandum,
and in particular those relating to our Finance industry vertical.

We have implemented what we believe to be adequate changes to reinforce our internal control systems
as well as oversight mechanisms to prevent the occurrence of similar accounting errors and we will
continue to strengthen them. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, no other incorrect accounting
practices similar to those uncovered in the Company’s Finance industry vertical and Nexen were
identified. In addition, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Company is not aware of any
investigations and/or proceedings of any nature initiated by public authorities in relation to the
accounting errors. If new accounting errors are identified in the future, our business and reputation may
be further harmed. The involvement or association of our employees in the intentional implementation
of similar conducts, or allegations or rumors relating thereto, could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition and results of operations or negatively affect our reputation. The
materialization of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results
of operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_Certain line items contained in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements and the 2021 Financial_**

Given the different scope of consolidation, the financial results of the Company and the Issuer are not
directly comparable. In particular, certain line items contained in the consolidated income statement
and balance sheet included in the 2021 Financial Statements (including the comparative financial data
for the period between March 20, 2020 (the date of incorporation of the Issuer) and December 31, 2020)
are not comparable to the corresponding line items contained in the Company’s 2020 Financial
Statements. In particular, the different scope of consolidation results with respect to the financial

also including, among others, indebtedness and cash at the level of the Issuer (including indebtedness
under the Existing Notes and the Existing Term Loan, and associated interest payments), which are not
otherwise included in the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements.

In addition, we have accounted for the Engineering Acquisition using the acquisition method of
accounting under IFRS and applied purchase accounting adjustments in connection with the
Engineering Acquisition to the financial statements for accounting periods subsequent to the
Engineering Acquisition Closing Date. However, the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements have not
been adjusted retrospectively to reflect the impact of any changes to the income statement, statement of


-----

financial position or cash flow statement that occurred as a result of purchase accounting adjustments
applied to the Engineering Acquisition. The most material differences between the financial information
as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2021 Financial Statements as compared
to the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements relate to amortization and depreciation, financial expenses
and income taxes. For example, amortization and depreciation for the year ended December 31, 2021
included in the 2021 Financial Statements was higher by €35.7* million compared to the Company’s
2020 Financial Statements. This is mainly due to incremental amortization charges of customer lists
and customer relationships recognized by the Issuer following completion of the Engineering
Acquisition. Financial expenses for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the Issuer’s
consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 was higher by €55.9*
million compared to the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements. This is mainly due to payment of €24.1
million in interest on the Existing Funding Loan and €37.8 million in interest payments by the Issuer
on the Existing Notes. Income taxes recorded in the audited consolidated financial statements as of and
for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the Issuer’s consolidated financial statements as of
and for the year ended December 31, 2021 were higher by €94.3* million compared to the Company’s
2020 Financial Statements. This is mainly due to the extraordinary release to the income statement for
the year ended December 31, 2020, of deferred tax liabilities relating to trademarks and other intangible
assets over the same period. Similar differences exist, _mutatis mutandis, with respect to the audited_
consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 included in the 2022
Audited Financial Statements. As a result of the differences described above, the audited consolidated
financial statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022 Audited Financial
Statements are not directly comparable to the information included in the Company’s 2020 Financial
Statements.
