Historically, we have funded our acquisitions primarily with cash from operations and, in the case of
the Movilitas Group and Atlantic Technologies, with drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit
Facility (which have been subsequently partially repaid) and, in the case of the Be Group, primarily
with drawings under the Bridge Facility (which we also used to reimburse drawings under the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility used to fund the Market Purchases). Going forward, we expect to fund any
additional acquisitions with a combination of cash on balance sheet and drawings under the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility, depending on our working capital and liquidity needs. In the years ended
December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022, we spent €20.9 million, €73.3 million, and €473.7 million,
respectively, as consideration paid for acquisitions of other businesses.

We believe our historical acquisition strategy has successfully increased our number of customers and
enabled us to expand our business to new market segments and a larger geographic area, while also
completing our product and service offerings which we can then offer to our existing and new
customers, particularly in the area of proprietary solutions.

Acquisitions and disposals affect our results of operations in a variety of ways. Our results for the period
during which an acquisition or disposal takes place and onwards are affected by the inclusion or
exclusion of the results of the acquired or disposed of business in our consolidated results. In addition,
the results of the acquired businesses after their acquisition may be impacted positively by synergies
arising from operational improvements and other cost savings or efficiency initiatives. We may also
experience an increase in operating expenses, including personnel cost, as we integrate the acquired
business into our network. Acquisitions may also result in higher levels of depreciation and amortization
expense. In addition, because acquired entities are consolidated from the date of their acquisition and
disposed entities are no longer consolidated from the date of their disposition, the full impact of an
acquisition or disposition is only reflected in our financial statements in the subsequent periods. As a
result, the historical results of operations for the periods presented in the Offering Memorandum may
not be fully comparable with each other or with our future results. In 2020, we completed the
Engineering Acquisition and began to report our financial results in respect of periods following the
Engineering Acquisition at the level of the Issuer, in accordance with IFRS. The impact of this
acquisition limits the comparability of our results from period to period. See “—Key Factors Affecting
_the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—The Engineering Acquisition in 2020.”_

With the acquisition of FDL Servizi S.r.l., a company providing software for smart grid-management,
in 2020, we expanded our presence in our Energy & Utilities and Public Administration industry
verticals, while increasing the share of Proprietary Solutions. In 2021, we completed several additional
acquisitions in Italy and abroad. In Italy, we acquired the smart working and collaboration platform for
businesses from Livebox S.r.l., Nexera S.p.A., a company specializing in the provision of IT solutions


-----

for advanced security systems and healthcare through proprietary solutions, as well as C Consulting
S.p.A., a company operating in the reinsurance market, which enabled us to both enrich our product
portfolio dedicated to financial institutions and insurance companies through high quality proprietary
solutions and to expand our IFRS and Solvency II consulting capabilities. In addition, we significantly
expanded our footprint in the United States through the acquisition of a business unit of Design
Automation Associates Inc., a digital automation player focusing on product design, analysis and test
engineering, and the Movilitas Group, an established U.S. player in the consulting space offering smart
solutions for the manufacturing industry which enhanced our industry 4.0 offering in the areas of
product tracking and tracing, digital twin, asset performance management and warehouse management.
These acquisitions enabled us to significantly strengthen our digital product and service offering in the
United States, which resulted in a €56.3 million increase in revenues generated in the United States,
from €15.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €71.5 million for the year ended December
31, 2022. As part of our growth strategy, in 2020 we completed the spin-off of our subsidiary Sofiter
Tech S.r.l., which has exited the consolidation perimeter of the Group with effect from November 30,
2020. In addition, in 2021, as part of our growth strategy, we also completed the spin-off of our
subsidiary OverIT S.p.A., which has exited the consolidation perimeter of the Group with effect from
December 1, 2021. In 2022, we continued to strengthen our portfolio by completing the acquisition of
PluSure S.p.A., an Italian company specialized in product lifecycle management solutions and the
acquisition of Atlantic Technologies S.p.A., an Italian company specialized in implementing cloud
technology in the area of CRM, ERP and analytics which we believe will increase our exposure to high
digital growth platforms, while strengthening our consulting capabilities and reinforcing our expertise
in driving digitalization processes. Atlantic Technologies is an international leading partner of
Salesforce, Infor, Tableau and Orable, and assists its customers in enabling opportunities for recurring
business generation. Atlantic Technologies employs approximately 200 specialized and certified
professionals, working on over 2,000 projects across three offices strategically located in Milan, London
and Denver. In 2022, Atlantic Technologies revenues grew by 32.1% to €25.9 million, through the
acquisition of PluSure S.p.A., we expanded our product design solutions portfolio aimed at our industry
4.0 customers, and strengthened the positioning on the European markets of our eXcellence global
division. In addition, the acquisition of Atlantic Technologies enabled us to deepen our expertise in
driving the digitization processes of customers, through the consolidation of its longstanding experience
in operational consulting and the development of innovative digitalization paths.

We believe that the acquisitions we made in the periods under review have generated synergies for our
business and have contributed to our organic growth. Such acquisitions have given us, for example, the
ability to cross-sell the new products and services we acquired to our existing customer base and to
complete our product and service offering while, among other things, strengthening our design
integration and delivery capabilities for end-to-end lifecycle solutions targeting industrial products.
Once the acquired business is fully integrated in our business, we aim to increase its volumes of
operations leveraging our integrated platform.

In addition, the successful acquisition of the Be Group, which we completed in December 2022,

In the future, we intend to continue to grow our business, through organic growth and highly targeted,

**_Investments in Research and Innovation and Capital Expenditures_**

To maintain our competitive position, we continuously invest in research and innovation and work to
create new products and integrate the results of our research into our digital-enabling technologies and
competences with an aim to continuously improve our IT solution offerings across all of our industry
verticals. In particular, as of December 31, 2022, we were involved in more than 100 research projects
implemented in over ten of our research labs, which are all located in Italy. We invested approximately
€25 million in 2022 in R&D, with a R&D Lab department relying on a team of over 500 professionals,
which includes researchers and data scientists (both directly part of our R&D Lab department) and
employees from our Development Labs, Competence Centers and Products Labs, who work in close
cooperation with our R&D Labs. In addition, we maintain over 150 global university partnerships with
strategic alliances encompassing our global research partner ecosystem, which includes universities,
research centers, technology companies and end-user companies. We typically capitalize the costs
related to the development of a new software or digital platform as an intangible asset and amortize it
over the useful life of the product (between three to six years). In addition, we typically capitalize
expenses for substantial updates to our existing product portfolio and add them to the original cost of
the underlying software or platform. Additionally, we generally expense development costs that
improve product performance or that are related to product upgrades as a result of regulatory
requirements in the projects that we create for our customers during the period in which they are
incurred.

Our business is characterized by low levels of recurring capital expenditures in line with the industry in
which we operate. Our capital expenditures for the periods under review primarily related to
investments in our three data centers. We incurred €15.5* million, €23.3* million and €54.6 million of
capital expenditures in the years ended December 31, 2020 2021 and 2022, respectively, representing
1.3%*, 1.8%* and 3.8% of our revenues, respectively. For further information, see “—Capital
_expenditure.”_

**_Our Cost Structure and Cost Savings and Efficiency Initiatives_**

Our cost structure is partially fixed. In the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022, fixed costs
accounted for 62%*, 61%* and 58% of our total operating expenses, respectively. Personnel expenses,
which represented 55%*, 52% and 50% of our total operating expenses in the years ended December
31, 2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively, are the largest part of our cost structure and are largely fixed
due to our reliance on our skilled workforce to run our business, other than a small portion relating to
variable compensation and travel expenses. Other key fixed costs include rents and leases. The majority
of our variable and discretionary costs is represented by costs incurred to pay for external consultants
(approximately 4,700 in the year ended December 31, 2022) that we use to manage peaks of demand
from customers and which increase the flexibility of our cost structure. We account for these costs as
service costs in our income statement. Following completion of the Be Acquisition and consolidation
of the Be Group into our business, we have added approximately 1,934 new employees to our Group,
based on the number of employees of the Be Group as of December 31, 2022. The addition of Be
Group’s employees has further increased our fixed costs. Be Group’s personnel costs amounted to €79.6
million, €104.3 million and €132.3 million, respectively, for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021
and 2022.

In order to support our resilient business model and increase our margins, starting in 2017 we launched
a number of cost saving initiatives with the aim of streamlining our operations and achieve annual run
rate cost savings, including management of vendors’ rates, workforce optimization measures such as
the near-shoring of approximately 270 full-time (as at December 31, 2022) employees to Serbia, as well
as other cost-saving initiatives regarding for example the reduction of travel expenses.

In addition, starting in 2022, we began implementing a comprehensive range of cost savings and
efficiency initiatives aimed at enhancing our operations and improving our ability to respond to changes
in the demand for our products and solutions, by further increasing the flexibility of our cost structure.


-----

In the aggregate, we expect our cost savings and efficiency initiatives to generate €16.2 million of
annual run rate cost savings by the end of 2023 (€9.8 million of which have been already achieved for
the year ended December 31, 2022), based on management’s assumptions regarding the impact of such
actions in the year ended December 31, 2022. We incurred approximately €2.5 million of one-off costs
in connection with the achievement of these cost savings, primarily related to the involvement of a third
party supplier with proven expertise in technology procurement and supply chain dynamics, and we
expect to only incur further de minimis costs for the achievement thereof. Once achieved, we expect
that these cost savings will structurally reduce the Group’s cost base going forward.

In particular, our key cost savings and efficiency initiatives include:

(A) Procurement initiatives, consisting of:

(i) the streamlining of our contractual relationships with external IT consultants through the

introduction of (x) competitive tender procedures, which involve our central procurement
function in each tender and (y) a structured supplier qualification process that we expect
will enable us to rely on a sub-set of preferred providers under optimized fee arrangements,
which we started implementing in the first and second quarter of 2022, respectively. ; and

## (ii) the reduction of costs related to the procurement of software products, primarily by (x)

consolidating our current software providers base into a limited number of distributors and
resellers, and (y) consolidating our IT spend with certain selected OEMs into few selected
contractual arrangements, which we started implementing in each case in the second quarter
of 2022;

We estimate that by the end of 2023, these procurement initiatives will generate €10.0 million
of run rate cost savings (€4.0 million of which have been already achieved for the year ended
December 31, 2022), representing approximately 2% of our estimated total addressable IT
consulting spend in 2022.

(B) optimization initiatives targeting the reduction of utilities, maintenance and rent costs related
to our real estate portfolio, including the reduction of our square footage at multiple locations
and office closures in up to three out of 13 non-strategic locations in Italy as well as the opening
of a new Group flagship office in Milan (Italy) with the aim of strengthening our image and
talent attractiveness, which we started implementing in the second quarter of 2022. We estimate
that by 2023, the run rate cost savings obtained through these activities will more than offset
rising utility prices and generate aggregate cost savings of €1.6 million (net of costs we expect
to incur in connection with the opening of the new Group flagship office in Milan), €1.2 million
of which have been already achieved for the year ended December 31, 2022; and

(C) a broad range of other cost saving initiatives, including the outsourcing of payroll activities, the
implementation of headcount optimization and reduction projects including nearshoring
activities in Serbia and adjacent countries, the rationalization projects aimed at consolidating
our legal structure, and vendor rebate management activities, which we started implementing
in part in the first quarter of 2022. These initiatives generated €4.6 million of run rate cost
savings, which have already been achieved for the year ended December 31, 2022.

In addition, we expect to generate approximately €9.5 million of further cost savings by the end of 2024
in connection with the Be Acquisition from the integration of the Be Group into our business. Once
achieved, we expect that these cost savings will structurally reduce the Group’s cost base going forward.
See “—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—The impact of the Be
_Acquisition.”_

We believe that the implementation of these cost savings synergies and efficiency initiatives will result
in a lower and more flexible cost base, which we can adjust to levels of customer and market demand,
thus resulting in reduced operating leverage. While it is our objective to reach the levels of projected


-----

cost savings in the timeframe and amounts reflected above, we cannot give any assurance that we will
be able to realize all or any portion of these cost savings and efficiency initiatives within the anticipated
timeframe or at all, or that additional or unanticipated costs will not arise, which will make it more
costly to realize such savings and the costs to be incurred in trying to realize these cost savings synergies
may be substantially higher than our current estimates and may outweigh the benefits. Our anticipated
cost savings synergies are based on assumptions about our ability to implement these measures in a
timely fashion and within certain cost parameters. If one or more of our underlying assumptions
regarding these initiatives proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher
costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or realize in the anticipated timeframe, the
expected benefits. In addition, the above information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties and
may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial impact or results of these actions and
initiatives for the period presented. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—
_Our cost saving measures may prove to be ineffective” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our_
_Business and Industry—We may not realize any or all of the adjustments to Pro Forma Run Rate_
_Adjusted EBITDA included in this Offering Memorandum.”_

**_Accounts Receivable, Days Sales Outstanding (“DSO”) and Amounts Overdue_**

We generally issue invoices to our customers on a monthly basis and they are generally required to pay
us within 60 days from receipt of the relevant invoice. While we believe our typical payment terms are
consistent with those of our peers, from time to time, in the ordinary course of business, we carry
significant accounts receivable on our balance sheet from customers that generate a large portion of our
revenues. The lengths of payment cycles for services rendered vary across our different industry
verticals as well as the type of customer we serve. In particular, our public sector clients typically have
longer payment cycles (averaging approximately 260 days) than our private sector clients (averaging
about 170 days). Excluding the effect of non-recourse sales of receivables (both on a spot-basis and
under the Intesa Securitization Programs), our average DSOs in trade receivables, excluding the trade
receivables from Sicilia Digitale S.p.A, in the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, was
approximately 195, 219 and 217 days, respectively. As of December 31, 2022, our overdue trade
receivables from public and private sector customers amounted to €84.5 million (of which €28.9 million
were due from Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and Regione Sicilia) and €82.6 million, respectively.

We mainly experience overdue receivables from our public sector customers within our Health and
Public Administration industry verticals, which is a common characteristic of commercial relationships
between public entities and their private counterparts in Italy. Historically, the level of overdue
receivables from customers in our Public Administration industry vertical often comprised 50% or more
of the total amount of receivables due from our Public Administration customers. Additionally,
customers within our Health industry vertical have the largest proportion of receivables that have been
overdue for more than 120 days. Public sector-related customers sometimes follow payment
management processes that are subject to review by other government authorities or other entities,
which may cause delays or adjustments to their own payment schedules. Overdue receivables from our
private sector customers occur primarily within our Industry & Services industry vertical, followed by
our Finance, Energy & Utilities and Telco & Media industry verticals and mainly relate to small- to
medium-sized enterprises. Following completion of the Be Acquisition and consolidation of the Be
Group into our business, we have increased the number of our Public Administration customers,
including portion of public sector-related ones. While the portion of revenues the Be Group generates
from its entire pool of Public Administration customers is limited (amounting to €0.1 million, €0.1
million and €1.5 million, respectively, in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022) an
increase in the number of Public Administration customers we serve following the acquisition of the
Be Group may have an impact on our overall overdue receivables. Following the consolidation of the
Be Group into our business, the majority of the revenues generated by Be Group’s Public
Administration customers has been included into our Public Administration industry vertical.

Delays in payments by our largest customers, requests for modifications to their contractual payment
arrangements or defaults on their payment obligations to us could affect our cash flow and results of


-----

operations. For example, as of the date of the Offering Memorandum, we are involved, through our
controlled subsidiary, SISEV, in two disputes against Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and Regione Sicilia for
total unpaid amounts of €131.1 million in nominal value related to the IT activities connected with the
building of an integrated IT platform for Regione Sicilia, within specifications and provisions set out in
the convention signed between Regione Sicilia, Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and SISEV, which expired on
December 22, 2013. As of December 31, 2022, our total exposure to Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and Regione
Sicilia amounted to €131.1 million, including €64.2 million of trade receivables and €14.5 million of
customer contract assets. Our trade receivables from Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and Regione Sicilia included
receivables on invoices issued (€28.9 million), invoices to be issued (€35.4 million) and interest in
arrears (€52.3 million). As of December 31, 2022, we recorded a doubtful debt provision in relation to
these receivables amounting to €27.8 million and a related doubtful debt provision for interest on arrears
amounting to €52.3 million. As of December 31, 2022, our net exposure to Sicilia Digitale and Regione
Sicilia amounted to €40.9 million (€26.4 million, excluding €14.5 million of customer contract assets).
Except for receivables due from Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and Regione Sicilia, we believe we have a good
track-record of collecting outstanding payments.

We mitigate our exposure to the risks relating to the collection of receivables through constant
monitoring of our commercial exposure and the collection times of receivables, which we track
excluding the effects of non-recourse sales of receivables. We have a dedicated team focused on
receivables collection and our sales representatives’ variable bonus includes DSO annual targets. In
addition, from time to time, we engage in the sale of receivables on the basis of uncommitted or
committed framework factoring agreements to manage our working capital especially closer to the end
of each fiscal quarter and the fiscal year. In March 2022, we entered into the First Intesa Securitization
Program, consisting a new committed framework factoring agreement with a vehicle controlled by
Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. providing for non-recourse sales of receivables for an aggregate amount of up
to €150.0 million at any time outstanding. As of December 31, 2022, €110.7 million were outstanding
under the First Intesa Securitization Program, while €39.3 million were available for drawing. In
addition, in October 2021 we entered into the Second Intesa Securitization Program, which provides
for the non-recourse sales of receivables from Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. For the year ended December 31,
2022, we have sold €122.6 million trade receivables under the Second Intesa Securitization Program.
See “Description of Certain Other Financing Arrangements—Existing Company Indebtedness—Intesa
_Securitization Programs.” See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.” We intend to primarily rely on_
our operating cash flow and on sales of receivables under our Intesa Securitization Programs and on a
spot basis, as well as our Existing Revolving Credit Facility to satisfy our working capital and other
liquidity needs.

**_Revenue generation, cash collection and billing patterns_**

To a certain extent, we are subject to revenue generation, cash collection and billing patterns. In
particular, while our cash collection is stable during the first two quarters of each year on the back of
the ongoing fees we receive by customers under all our ongoing contracts, our cash collection usually
peaks during the fourth quarter of each year due to the finalization of accounts and payment of invoices
by our customers in anticipation of the end of the financial year. Our cash collection is typically lowest
during the third quarter of each year due primarily to extended school holidays in Italy during the month
of August. Maintenance fees are typically collected quarterly and yearly, starting from when the initial
purchase order is made by the relevant customer. Our billing cycle and the recognition of revenues in
our income statement is typically subject to similar drivers, with a stable level of revenues recorded in
the first two quarters of each year, when we collect purchase orders from customers, and the highest
revenues recorded during the third and fourth quarter of each year when we typically issue invoices to
our customers in connection with the formalization of purchase orders as binding contracts and the
finalization of our yearly accounts. Our working capital levels are also subject to similar drivers, with
our working capital levels typically peaking in September of each year, in connection with payments of
invoices by our customers, before gradually declining to their low point in December of each year.

From time to time, we carry significant accounts receivable balances from a limited number of
customers that generate a large portion of our revenues. In addition, we engage in the sale of receivables
on the basis of uncommitted or committed framework non-recourse factoring agreements in order to
support our working capital and liquidity needs. In March 2022, we entered into the First Intesa
Securitization Program, consisting of a new committed framework factoring agreement with a vehicle
controlled by Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. providing for non-recourse sales of receivables for an aggregate
amount of up to €150.0 million at any time outstanding. As of December 31, 2022, €110.7 million were
outstanding under the First Intesa Securitization Program, while €39.3 million were available for
drawing. In addition, in October 2021 we entered into the Second Intesa Securitization Program, which
provides for the non-recourse sales of receivables from Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. For the year ended


-----

December 31, 2022, we have sold €122.6 million trade receivables under the Second Intesa
Securitization Program. See “Description of Certain Other Financing Arrangements—Existing
_Company Indebtedness—Intesa Securitization Programs.” See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.”_
We intend to primarily rely on our operating cash flow and on sales of receivables under our Intesa
Securitization Programs and on a spot basis, as well as our Existing Revolving Credit Facility to satisfy
our working capital and other liquidity needs. Billed and unbilled receivables, as well as DSOs in
accounts receivable, net of deferred revenue, can vary based on the timing and size of cash receipts.
Typically, receivables sold through non-recourse sales of receivables are written off from our financial
statements upon their transfer, as all risks and benefits of the factored receivables are irrevocably
transferred to the transferee. As a result of sales of receivables under the Intesa Securitization Programs
and other spot sales of receivables, as of December 31, 2022, as part of our receivables management
strategy and to support our M&A activity we sold €787.8 million of trade receivables on a non-recourse
basis, €133.3 million of which were still outstanding at period end (excluding €121.2 million of trade
receivables sold on a non-recourse basis by Be, €39.6 million of which were still outstanding as of
December 31, 2022). Prior to the Be Acquisition, Be also engaged in the sale of receivables on the basis
of non-recourse factoring agreements.

Our results of operations are also affected by varying billing and invoicing patterns among our different
activity types, industry verticals and types of customers. Sales cycles vary among our different industry
verticals and types of customers, with the time between the date a contract is entered into and the
beginning of the provision of services ranging from an average of six months for private sector
customers to one to two years for contracts awarded under public tenders. Because we recognize
revenues only upon the actual provision of the contracted services and achievement of other recognition
criteria, the financial benefit of gaining a new client may not be realized at the intended time due to
delays in the implementation of our services or due to an increase in the start-up costs required in
building our infrastructure.

**_Italian and global macroeconomic conditions, market trends and customer demands_**

We primarily operate our business in Italy where we generated 82% and 88%* of our revenues for the
years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively. In addition, our headquarters
and our three data centers are located in Italy. As a result, although our revenues have remained resilient
through volatile macroeconomic cycles during the past 20 years, with our revenues’ organic growth
continuously outperforming Italian GDP growth on a year-over-year basis, macroeconomic conditions,
political instability, market trends and customer demand in Italy have a significant impact on our results
of operations. Prior to 2015, IT services spend in Italy generally grew in line with GDP growth after
which growth in IT services spend increasingly outperformed the Italian GDP growth. See “Industry
_and Market Overview—Large and attractive addressable markets.” Between 2019 and 2021, the Italian_
ICT Services and Software & Solutions markets grew at a CAGR of approximately 4.4% and were
worth approximately €21.8 billion in 2021 (and such markets are expected to have grown to €23 billion
in 2022), according to Anitec-Assinform. This growth was primarily driven by ongoing digitalization
across the Italian public and private sectors and increasing spending in transformation projects from
traditional IT to new digital enabling technologies, which further increased underpinned by PNRR
adopted in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Our results of operations and financial condition are also impacted by other global macroeconomic
factors such as the prevailing market interest rates, overall inflation levels and energy and logistics
costs. In particular, increases in interest rates, which are determined and controlled by central banks in
response to macroeconomic events (including the recent December 2022, February 2023 and March
2023 increases by the European Central Bank), may negatively affect general economic growth in the
countries in which we operate and, consequently, could have a negative impact on the demand for our
solutions as well as our financing costs. On the other hand, inflation surges and the increase in energy
costs may have a negative impact on our cost base and overall profitability levels. While our customers
in the Industry & Services vertical have been negatively impacted by rising energy costs, this has not
resulted in a slowdown of our business in the year ended December 31, 2022. Rising energy costs have


-----

primarily impacted our cost base but did not have any direct negative impacts on our business
operations. While we do not maintain a hedging strategy in place for our energy costs, in light of the
current macroeconomic conditions we are reviewing the structure of our customer contracts and are
planning to include inflation pass-through provisions going forward.

In addition, partly as a result of the ongoing interest rate surge, in March 2023, Silicon Valley Bank,
one of the largest U.S. banks in the technology sector, collapsed, representing the largest global bank
failure since the 2008 financial crisis and requiring immediate government intervention. This collapse
caused challenges for several U.S. regional banks and was shortly followed by the shutdown by U.S.
regulators of a smaller U.S.-based bank, Signature Bank, and the downfall in Credit Suisse’s share price,
which was followed, in turn, by the announced merger brokered by Swiss authorities between Credit
Suisse and UBS. The pressure on U.S. regional banks has continued, leading to the announcement by
the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on May 1, 2023, that First Republic Bank, a California based
regional bank, would be taken over by JPMorgan Chase. While the situation continues to develop and
the industry-wide impact of these events is not yet clear, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum,
it is not possible to predict the impact that these events failures may have on the U.S. and global banking
and financial systems and monetary policy, and any potential associated effect on the Italian economy,
the economies of the other countries where we operate and, in turn, on our customers operating in the
financial sector. The failure or financial distress of any of our our lenders or financial counterparties or
those of our customers, could materially adversely affect our liquidity and ability to fund our ongoing
working capital needs and general corporate purposes. A deterioration of the international financial
systems could also result in less favorable commercial financing terms, including higher interest rates
or costs and tighter financial and operating covenants, or systemic limitations on access to credit and
liquidity sources, which could negatively impact our ability to acquire financing on acceptable terms or
at all. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Continued increases in
_electricity costs may adversely affect our results of operations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to_
_Our Business and Industry—Our business may be adversely affected by global economic conditions,_
_political events and geopolitical conflicts, including political and economic uncertainty in Italy and_
_Europe.”_

**_Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic_**

Following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Italian economy contracted sharply during
2020, recording a year-on-year contraction in GDP of 8.9% (source: ISTAT) as the country was one of
the hardest hit and several lockdowns and other restrictive measures were imposed. The global COVID19 pandemic has had a material impact on economic activity across our markets and on our business
operations, particularly in 2020. For example, to manage our cost structure and reduce our cash burn,
in connection with the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, for the year ended December 31, 2020,
we reduced our travel costs by €17.3 million, compared to the year ended December 31, 2019, and
placed a limited number of our projects as well as employees within certain specific functions (such as
our internal travel agency and the employees of our tax collection business, Municipia S.p.A.) on
temporary government subsidy programs, which drove a reduction of our personnel costs in 2020
compared to 2019. The restrictions imposed in the context of the first outbreak of the COVID-19
pandemic also resulted in lower service costs due to a decrease in the utilization of external professional
resources in our business. Due to the removal and loosening of the various restrictions imposed by
governments to counter the spread of COVID-19 in 2020 and in light of the related improving
macroeconomical framework in 2021, we fully reduced our reliance on the abovementioned
governmental subsidy programs and increased the number of external professional resources in our
operations, which led to an increase in both personnel costs and service costs in 2021 compared to 2020.

Despite the limited revenue decline caused by outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020, certain industry verticals
proved to be resilient. In particular, in the year ended December 31, 2020, we experienced an increase
in revenues across two of our six verticals (Health and Public Administration, which increased by 11.2%
and 3.7%, respectively, compared to 2019), primarily as a result of increased customer demand for our
digital solutions driven by the COVID-19 pandemic and the restrictions and lockdown measures


-----

imposed in response thereto. Revenues in our Finance industry vertical remained stable as a result of
increased sales generated by consulting solutions. On the other hand, we experienced a revenue decline
in our Industry & Services vertical (by 6.8%), particularly due to reduced demand from customers in
the leisure travel and cruise industry, and in our Telco & Media industry vertical (by 18.3%),
particularly as a result of the significant reduction in volumes generated on _Mobile VAS, a platform_
enabling mobile operators to sell value-added products and services to customers with subscriptions,
resulting from restrictions imposed by the competent Italian authorities on the use of services through
such platform by such mobile operators. In addition, new requirements were introduced over the same
period by the competent Italian authorities for operators to implement new control and safety measures
in connection with their customer acquisition processes, which requirements drove a 80% decrease of
revenues from our sales of customer acquisition processes solutions to customers in the Telco & Media
industry vertical in 2020 compared to 2019. Such reduction in revenues has also continued in
subsequent periods and while we recorded revenues of €1.5* million from Mobile VAS solutions in the
year ended December 31, 2021, these declined to approximately €0.5 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. As a result, revenues generated from Mobile VAS are no longer material.

Throughout 2021 and 2022, the Italian GDP experienced a rebound, and grew year-on-year by 6.5%
and 3.8%, respectively. Over the same period, our business has begun to experience stronger rates of
growth. In particular, in the year ended December 31, 2021, our overall revenues increased across all
of our industry verticals, with the strongest increase in our Health industry vertical, which was 25.3*%
higher compared to 2020. This increase was primarily due to the award of new contracts as well as
additional healthcare investments by our existing customers, which were driven by the COVID-19
pandemic. Over the same period revenues generated in our Industry & Services industry also increased
by 12.2%*, compared to 2020, driven among others by a global macroeconomic recovery from COVID19 positively impacting customers in the automotive and transportation sectors mainly due to the
removal or loosening of the majority of the restrictions, including on travel, that had been imposed to
limit the spread of COVID-19 in 2020. Overall, our revenues in the year ended December 31, 2021
increased by 6.5%* compared to 2020. See “—Results of Operations—Year Ended December 31, 2020
_compared with Year Ended December 31, 2021.”_

We believe that the COVID-19 pandemic’s impact on our supply chain has been limited, as our
suppliers and partners have been able to work remotely and we benefit from a limited reliance on
physical product deliveries. Overall, since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have
experienced a general increase in customer demand for digitalization products and services across
almost all of our industry verticals, as businesses and public administration entities have been forced to
rely on their IT infrastructures and systems and have turned to remote working and cloud-based
solutions to run their operations.

As a result of the significant impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our results of operations, the
comparability of our results for the periods under review (particularly for the year ended December 31,
2021 compared to the year ended December 31, 2020), with the relevant corresponding periods and the
comparability with future periods may be limited.

**_Public ICT spending and our ability to continue to being awarded contracts by Public Administration_**
**_customers as a result of successful public tenders_**

A substantial portion of our revenues, and, particularly, revenues generated through our Public
Administration industry vertical, has been and will continue to be generated by sales to our public sector
customers in Italy. Substantially all of the services we provide to these customers are awarded through
public tender processes. Given the significance of the Public Administration industry vertical to our
results, the level of spending by governmental and other public entities on technological infrastructure
and other technology-related investments is important to our business.

According to the Italian government’s official figures, government spending on information and
communication technology was estimated at €6.2 billion in 2020, and is projected to have increased to


-----

€6.5 billion in 2021, and to €7.0 billion in 2022, compared to a €5.6 billion average spending level
between 2016 and 2018. Any increase or decrease in such public spending could impact our customers’
available budgets and, consequently, our results of operations. In addition, Italy’s PNRR approved by
the European Commission in June 2021, supports the digital transition with expected additional
information and communication technology investments, particularly with respect to its (a) “Mission
1”, which allocates a budget of approximately €30 billion to investments in digitalization, innovation,
competitiveness, culture and tourism, including in the following areas: (ii) digital transition, innovation
and competitiveness of the Italian production system, by means of grants and incentives including for
4.0 technologies and training (€20.8 billion by 2026), and (iii) enhanced digitalization of the Italian
public sector (€ 5.9 billion by 2026), and its (b) “Mission 6”, which allocates a budget of approximately
€11 billion to investments in innovation, research and digitalization of the national healthcare system.
Current political instability in Italy may however jeopardize the implementation of the PNRR and result
in the delay, suspension and/or discontinuation of any programs aimed at encouraging IT spend. See
“Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Our business may be adversely affected
_by global economic conditions, political events and geopolitical conflicts, including political and_
_economic uncertainty in Italy and Europe.”_

Our continued success in being awarded contracts as a result of public tenders by Public Administration
customers depends, among other things, on the availability and quality of the contracts put out to tender,
which in turn is driven by Italian and EU government budgets and policies, as well as our ability to
anticipate and effectively respond to changes in market trends. Our success will also depend on our
ability to estimate resources and costs in the context of a competitive tender process in order to quote
at a competitive yet profitable pricing level, should the tender be successful. Further, our success will
depend on our ability to adapt to the stricter regulatory requirements required for participating in
governmental contracts.

The Issuer was incorporated on March 20, 2020 in connection with the Engineering Acquisition. As of
the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating
activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets, other than the shares it holds in the
Company and its receivables under the Existing Funding Loan and the Overlord Funding Loan I, or
material liabilities, other than those incurred in connection with its incorporation, the Engineering
Acquisition and the transactions related thereto, including the Existing Notes, the Existing Revolving
Credit Facility, the Existing Term Loan and the €210.0 million deeply subordinated shareholder loan
granted by TopCo to the Issuer in 2020 in connection with the Engineering Acquisition. Because the

operations of the Issuer only, without any results from the Group prior to the Engineering Acquisition
Closing Date, and (ii) approximately five months of operations of the Group after the Engineering
Acquisition Closing Date. As a result, in this Offering Memorandum we present and discuss historical
financial information for the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries for periods prior to such date,

different scope of consolidation, the financial results of the Company and the Issuer are not directly

the increase of our share of captured customer spending, particularly in relation to the amount tier 2
bank institutions and insurance companies regularly devotes to the type of services that we offer (i.e.,
share of wallet), with a view of leveraging a joint new approaching strategy of the Group.

The achievement of the cost savings and synergies described above partly depends on factors that are
outside of our control, and we may be unable to implement some or all of such initiatives and/or generate
the expected benefits therefrom within the expected timeframe or at all. See “Risk Factors—Risks
_Related to Our Business and Industry—We may not realize any or all of the adjustments to Pro Forma_
_Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA included in the Offering Memorandum” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related_
_to the Be Acquisition.”_

We have accounted for the Be Acquisition using the acquisition method of accounting under IFRS,
which will affect the comparability of our future consolidated financial statements with the 2022
Audited Financial Statements contained in this Offering Memorandum. We will apply purchase
accounting adjustments in connection with the Be Acquisition to our financial statements for accounting
periods subsequent to the year ended December 31, 2022. The application of purchase accounting will
result in different carrying values for existing assets and assets we may add to our balance sheet, which
may include intangible assets, such as goodwill, leasehold rights and software, and different
amortization and depreciation expenses. Due to these and other potential adjustments, our financial
statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made.

Furthermore, we have incurred a substantial amount of additional indebtedness as a result of the Be
Acquisition. As of December 31, 2022, adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, we would have had
total third-party financial indebtedness outstanding in the amount of €1,175.1 million, including €385.0
million representing the aggregate principal amount of the Notes offered hereby, €605.0 million
representing the aggregate principal amount of the Existing Notes, €50.0 million of outstanding debt
under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, €38.4 million representing the aggregate principal amount
of our Existing Term Loan, and €96.7 million of other Company indebtedness (including €53.7 million
of Be’s indebtedness). See “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—
_Existing Company Indebtedness.” In addition, following the Existing Revolving Credit Facility_
Increase, we have €195.0 million available for drawing under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility,
of which €50.0 million have been drawn to fund the acquisition of Atlantic Technologies at the end of
2022.

Our indebtedness may limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and
future business opportunities, since a substantial portion our cash flow from operations will be dedicated
to the repayment of our indebtedness, and this may place us at a competitive disadvantage as some of
our competitors are less leveraged.


-----

**_Impact of certain accounting errors_**

In September 2022, we became aware of certain discrepancies between budgeted and final financial
data as of August 2022 relating to the Company’s Finance industry vertical and its subsidiary Nexen
(which is part of the Finance industry vertical). As a result of such discrepancies, we initiated a process,
with the assistance from external advisors, in order to verify the accounting methods used for specific
jobs within the Company’s Finance industry vertical and Nexen.

This verification process, which was completed at the end of the fiscal year 2022, identified certain
accounting errors relating to the 2022 fiscal year and previous fiscal years, which resulted in an
overstatement of the Company’s consolidated balance sheet assets and operating profits. On this basis,
management determined that it was necessary to make certain corrections to the financial statements
and applied IAS 8 (Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors), which governs,
among other things, how to recognise and represent errors, including those from previous years.

Based on the results of the verification process, we quantified the following accounting effects:

(i) an overstatement of the Group’s operating profit and EBITDA for the year ended December

31, 2022, of €10.9 million; and

(ii) an overstatement of the balance sheet assets as of January 1, 2022 of €46.0 million.

While it was possible to allocate the effects of the accounting errors that occurred during 2022 to the
financial year ended December 31, 2022 due to the availability of current information on the progress
of the Finance industry vertical’s contracts, we were not able to allocate with certainty the €46.0 million
overstatement of balance sheet assets as of January 1, 2022 to any prior periods because of the way our
management systems close out jobs and of the lack of traceability inside the system for such an
accounting error.

With respect to the accounting treatment of the correction of errors relating to fiscal year 2022, these
were corrected prior to the approval of the 2022 Audited Financial Statements, as required by IAS 8
(par. 5), according to which “potential errors of the current financial year discovered in the same
_financial year shall be corrected before the publication of the financial statements is authorised.”_
Therefore, we corrected the relevant items in the income statement for the year ended December 31,
2022, generating a corresponding impact on the operating profit and EBITDA, which was rectified by
€10.9 million.

Following completion of the verification process carried out with respect to the Finance industry
vertical, we deemed it prudent to carry out further verification processes on all the other verticals of the
Company with the assistance of external advisors whose work was completed by the end of 2022. As
of the date of this Offering Memorandum, no incorrect accounting practices similar to those uncovered
in the Company’s Finance industry vertical and Nexen were identified. However, as a result of such
verification process, we prudentially made specific provisions of approximately €7.0 million (of which
€6.1 million relating to contract work in progress and €0.9 million to invoices to be issued) in our
balance sheet as of December 31, 2022, in respect of some positions relating to assets accrued mainly
in previous years and not invoiced, exclusively attributable to technical/commercial issues that emerged
during the execution of the jobs. Such €7.0 million provisions did not impact our consolidated EBITDA
for the year ended December 31, 2022.

As a result of the correction of the accounting errors in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements as
summarized above and the inability of the Issuer to quantify the above-mentioned corrections on net
income and shareholders’ equity for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, the consolidated
financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 contained in the 2022 Audited
Financial Statements included in the Offering Memorandum is not fully comparable with (i) the
financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Audited


-----

Financial Statements and the 2021 Financial Statements, and (ii) the financial information as of and for
the year ended December 31, 2020 derived from the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements. For the
same reasons, the financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 derived from
the Company’s 2020 Financial Statements is also not fully comparable with the financial information
as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements and
the 2021 Financial Statements. Neither the 2021 Financial Statements nor the Company’s 2020
Financial Statements are included in the Offering Memorandum.

As a consequence of the foregoing, throughout this Offering Memorandum, we have either marked any
such consolidated financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021,
including any related averages, ranges and growth rates, with an asterisk (“*”) or we have included
appropriate footnotes to the relevant financial tables as a reminder that each such financial information
may be affected by accounting errors. Investors should therefore exercise caution when comparing our
results of operations and balance sheet assets among the periods under review in this Offering
Memorandum, and in particular those relating to our Finance industry vertical.

Following the identification of the accounting errors described above, we have implemented what we
believe to be adequate changes to reinforce our internal control systems as well as oversight mechanisms
to prevent the implementation of similar accounting errors. The measures we deployed include: (i) an
intensified monitoring of our invoice cycle, (ii) the enhanced supervision of sales functions at each
industry vertical, (iii) the implementation of a new credit monitoring procedure, and (iv) the
centralization of internal control and risk functions previously performed by each industry vertical
independently. We also created a new “order management” function and strengthened our internal
control team, including by appointing a new credit manager.

See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our

**Description of Key Income Statement Items**

**_Revenues_**

Revenues means revenue from sales and services of products produced. In particular, this refers to
consultancy services, IT design, usage licenses, software maintenance services and outsourcing
services. For further information, see “—Accounting Policies—Revenue Recognition.”

**_Other income_**

Other income mainly refer to revenue from grants for research projects financed by national bodies and
by the European Union as well as “other income” which comprises revenues of various types, including
re-invoicing of fringe benefits to employees for use of company cars and corporate SIM cards for mobile
telephones.

**_Raw materials and consumables_**

Raw materials and consumables mainly consist of purchases of raw materials and goods, mainly
hardware and software and purchases of consumables, such as stationary paper.

**_Service costs_**


-----

Costs for services comprise: electronic data processing purchases, services and data lines; insurance;
bank commissions; technical support and consultancy; which represents the largest component, refers
to costs for services provided by external professional resources utilized in the Group’s operating and
production cycles and is therefore directly correlated to the Group’s revenue trends, consultancy from
associates; training and refresher courses; consultants; cost of corporate boards; building rental;
maintenance of tangible and intangible assets; canteen and other personnel costs; automotive expenses;
hardware and software rental; maintenance and security services; advertising and sales representative
expenses; travel costs; postage and shipping expenses; utilities; and other costs for services.

The “technical support and consultancy” item represents the largest component within the service costs
item and is related to costs incurred to pay for external professional resources, employed by the Group,
that we use in our production and operating cycle in order to manage peaks of activity. Therefore, trends
in this service cost line item are directly correlated to trends in our revenue.

**_Personnel costs_**

Personnel costs refer to salaries and wages, social security expenses; post-employment benefits,
restructuring and reorganizing personnel and other personnel costs.

Salaries and wages include costs related to holidays and leave pays, indemnities, overtime and bonuses.
Restructuring and reorganizing personnel item is related to the costs of incentives for employees leaving
early during the year. Personnel costs also includes costs for research undertaken in order to gain new
technical expertise, which are recorded in the income statement in the year in which they are incurred.
Other personnel costs include costs related to an employee stock option plan, as well as reclassification
of amortization and depreciation relating to cars assigned to employees, as required under IFRS 16.

**_Amortization and depreciation_**

Amortization and depreciation includes depreciation of property, plant and equipment, amortization of
intangible assets as well as depreciation and amortization resulting from the adoption of IFRS 16.

**_Provisions_**

Provisions consists of provisions allocated to bad debt, provisions allocated to risks and write-downs of
fixed assets. Amounts recognized under the provisions item represent the best estimates and
assumptions based on the best information available to management at the relevant reporting date.

**_Other costs_**

Other costs consist of dues and subscriptions, certain tax related costs (such as non-income charges
resulting from tax audits) gifts and donations, charges for social causes and other costs.

**_Financial income_**

Financial income includes interest income, fair value gain and gains on foreign exchange differences.
Interest income includes interest in arrears related to customer receivables from Sicilia Digitale S.p.A.
and Regione Sicilia. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.”

**_Financial expenses_**

Financial expenses consist of interest expenses and losses on foreign exchange differences. Interest
expenses mainly refer to financial expenses relating to certain loan agreements.

**_Income and expenses from investments_**

Income and expenses from investments consists of gains on equity investments, write-downs of equity
investments and non-recurring income or charges from investments.


-----

**_Income taxes_**

Income taxes consist of current taxes and deferred taxes. Taxes for any relevant period are estimated
taking into account the result for the period as well as the applicable laws and regulations, and represent
the best management estimate of the tax charge.

in sales of services and products across almost all our six industry vertical and, in particular, in our
Industry & Services, Health and Public Administration verticals. Our organic revenue growth from the
year ended December 31, 2021 to the year ended December 31, 2022 was 4.0%.

Revenues in the Finance industry vertical increased by €12.6 million, or 4.5%, from €279.1 million for
the year ended December 31, 2021 to €291.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This
increase was primarily due to the consolidation of the Be Group (€62.6 million) into our results, which
were offset by the impact of the internal investigation regarding the accounting errors described under
“Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Accounting Errors.”

Revenues in the Health industry vertical increased by €18.9 million, or 19.3%, from €98.1 million for
the year ended December 31, 2021 to €117.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This
increase was primarily due to higher sales to key Italian customers and the start of new projects we have
been awarded during the second half of 2022.

Revenues in the Industry & Services industry vertical increased by €82.0 million, or 28.0%, from €292.9
million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €374.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.


-----

This increase was primarily due to the consolidation into our results of PluSure S.p.A., the Movilitas
Group and Design Automation Associates Inc. and to higher sales in Italy driven by the inception of
new projects for key customers.

Revenues in the Telco & Media industry vertical decreased by €18.4 million, or 13.8%, from €133.5
million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €115.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.
This decrease was primarily due to lower sales from certain key customers, mainly driven by lower
sales to Telecom Italia and, to a lesser extent, Vodafone, BT and Median SIAE, partly offset by an
increase in sales towards Telco & Media customers in South America.

Revenues in the Energy & Utilities industry vertical increased by €10.6 million, or 5.3%, from €198.4
million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €209.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.
This increase was primarily due to an increase in sales of Proprietary Solutions products, as well as an
increase in sales volumes driven by the inception of new projects with key customers.

Revenues in the Public Administration industry vertical increased by €18.9 million, or 6.4%, from
€296.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €314.9 million for the year ended December
31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to a general increase in sales primarily driven by tenders
awarded by CONSIP and by public administration entities in the welfare sector.

_Raw materials and consumables_

Cost of raw materials and consumables increased by €23.2 million, or 66.1%, from €35.1 million for
the year ended December 31, 2021 to €58.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase
was primarily due to a €13.0 million increase in costs related to the resale of software products and a
€10.2 million increase in raw materials costs. Cost of raw materials and consumables accounted for
4.1% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared with 2.7% of our revenues for
the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Service costs_

Service costs increased by €65.2 million, or 14.8%, from €440.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2021 to €505.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to a
€17.5 million increase in costs related to external IT consultants and a €22.6 million increase in legal
and administrative consultancy costs, both driven by the combined effect of an increase in revenues and
the expansion of our consolidation perimeter. Service costs accounted for 35.6% of our revenues for
the year ended December 31, 2022, compared with 33.9% of our revenues for the year ended December
31, 2021.

_Personnel costs_

Personnel costs increased by €44.3 million, or 6.6%, from €674.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2021 to €718.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to
the combined effect of workforce salary increases and higher provisions for unused holidays and leave
periods. Personnel costs accounted for 50.5% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2022,
compared with 52.0% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Amortization and depreciation_

Amortization and depreciation increased by €6.2 million, or 6.5%, from €96.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021 to €103.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was
primarily due to the combined effect of a €5.2 million decrease in customer relationship amortization
costs and a €1.0 million decrease in amortization costs relating to the implementation of the IFRS 16
accounting standard, both partly offset by a €0.1 million increase in amortization costs relating to
intangible assets. Amortization and depreciation costs accounted for 7.2% of our revenues for the year
ended December 31, 2022, compared with 7.5% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.


-----

_Provisions_

Provisions increased by €27.8 million, or 122.5%, from €22.7 million for the year ended December 31,
2021 to €50.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to a €22.1
million increase in allocations to allowance for bad debt, and a €4.9 million increase in allocations to
risk provisions. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.” Provisions accounted for 3.5% of our revenues
for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to 1.7% of our revenues for the year ended December
31, 2021.

_Other costs_

Other costs decreased by €10.6 million, or (43.3)%, from €24.5 million for the year ended December
31, 2021 to €13.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to
the combined effect of a €4.5 million decrease in taxes other than income tax and a €6.8 million decrease
in other costs (driven by certain one-off costs incurred by our subsidiaries D.HUB and Cybertech),
partly offset by a €0.4 million increase in costs relating to dues and subscriptions. Other costs accounted
for 1.0% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to 1.9% of our revenues for
the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Financial income_

Financial income decreased by €0.5 million, or (4.7)%, from €10.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2021 to €10.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was mainly due to the
combined effect of a €5.1 million increase in income from exchange difference gains, offset by a €0.4
million decrease in fair value gains. and a €5.2 million decrease in interest income from receivables
towards Sicilia Digitale S.p.A. and Regione Sicilia, both relating to unpaid invoices.

_Financial expenses_

Financial expenses increased by €19.2 million, or 26.7%, from €71.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021 to €91.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily
due to the combined effect of a €8.2 million increase in expenses from foreign exchange losses and a
€11.0 million increase in interest expenses on the €210.0 million deeply subordinated shareholder loan
granted by TopCo to the Issuer in 2020, in connection with the Engineering Acquisition.

_Income taxes_

Income taxes increased by €13.7 million, or 214.1%, from a credit of €6.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021 to a credit of €20.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase
was primarily due to a €8.2 million increase in deferred taxes, driven by the accrual of tax loss advances
by our subsidiary D.HUB.

_Adjusted EBITDA_

Adjusted EBITDA increased by €9.5 million, or 4.8%, from €198.3 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021 to €207.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was
primarily due to the combined effect of (i) increased sales and higher margins reported by our Public
Administration, Healthcare, Energy & Utilities and Industry & Services industry verticals, and (ii) the
consolidation into our results of revenues contributed by acquisitions we completed over the year ended
December 31, 2022, partly offset by a decrease in Adjusted EBITDA generated by our Finance and
Telco & Media industry verticals.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Industry & Services industry vertical increased by €12.6 million, or 42.9%,
from €29.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €42.0 million for the year ended December
31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the combined effect of (i) higher sales margins by our
Italian and U.S. subsidiaries and (ii) the acquisitions of PluSure S.p.A., the Movilitas Group and Design
Automation Associates, Inc..

Adjusted EBITDA in the Telco & Media industry vertical decreased by €1.7 million, or (13.0)%, from
€13.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €11.4 million for the year ended December 31,


-----

2022. This decrease was primarily due to lower sales volumes and lower sales margins generated from
sales to certain telecommunications operators, partly offset by internal efficiencies.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Energy & Utilities industry vertical increased by €3.3 million, or 13.1%, from
€25.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €28.5 million for the year ended December 31,
2022. This increase was primarily due to an increase in sales of Proprietary Solutions products and the
inception of new projects with key customers.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Public Administration industry vertical increased by €6.4 million, or 17.3%,
from €36.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €43.3 million for the year ended December
31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to increased sales driven by the award of tenders and higher
profitability of projects managed during the period.

_Revenues_

Revenues increased by €79.5 million, or 6.5%, from €1,218.5 million for the year ended December 31,
2020 to €1,298.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an
increase in sales of services and products across all our six industry verticals, including as a result of
the recovery of the economy on the back of the measures adopted in response to the COVID-19
pandemic (such as the PNRR) and, in particular, the Industry & Services industry vertical, as well as
the full consolidation into our results of new companies and businesses acquired, in particular the
Movilitas group. Excluding revenues generated by our mobile payments business, our revenues in the
year ended December 31, 2021, would have been €1,296.4 million, an increase of €87.2 million (or
7.2%) compared to €1,209.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. Our organic revenue growth
from the year ended December 31, 2020 to the year ended December 31, 2021 was 6.4%.

Revenues in the Finance industry vertical increased by €4.5 million, or 1.6%, from €274.6 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020 to €279.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This
increase was primarily due to increased revenues from our key customers, such as UniCredit and BNPP,
as well as the inception of new customer projects with Intesa Sanpaolo following its acquisition of UBI,
partly offset by a decrease in sales of third-party licenses.

Revenues in the Health industry vertical increased by €19.8 million, or 25.3%, from €78.3 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020 to €98.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase
was primarily due to revenues generated by new contracts won with multiple Italian Regions and
additional healthcare investments by existing customers in the context of the outbreak of COVID-19.

Revenues in the Industry & Services industry vertical increased by €31.8 million, or 12.2%, from €261.1
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €292.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.
This increase was primarily due to (i) increased sales in the United States following our acquisition of
Design Automation Associates Inc., (ii) increased sales driven by our eXcellence global division and
(iii) a global macroeconomic recovery from COVID-19 positively impacting customers in the
automotive and transportation sectors.

Revenues in the Telco & Media industry vertical increased by €2.8 million, or 2.1%, from €130.7
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €133.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.
This increase was primarily due to revenues generated by new contracts with major telecommunications
companies. Excluding revenues generated by our mobile payments business, revenues in our Telco &
Media industry vertical in the year ended December 31, 2021, would have been €131.9 million, an
increase of €10.5 million (or 8.7%) compared to €121.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020.

Revenues in the Energy & Utilities industry vertical increased by €2.1 million, or 1.1%, from €196.3
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €198.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.
This increase was primarily due to higher sales volumes driven by our Net@Suite solution and increased
revenues from ENEL.

Revenues in the Public Administration industry vertical increased by €18.6 million, or 6.7%, from
€277.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €296.0 million for the year ended December
31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to revenues from the award of new contracts by central
governmental agencies and local entities, as a consequence of successful tenders.

_Raw materials and consumables_

Cost of raw materials and consumables decreased by €4.5 million, or 11.4%, from €39.6 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020 to €35.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease
was primarily due to a decrease of €6.8 million in costs associated with the resale of software products,
from €32.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €25.5 million for the year ended December
31, 2021, which was driven by our operating performance for the period. Cost of raw materials and
consumables accounted for 3.2% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to
2.7% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.


-----

_Service costs_

Service costs increased by €47.0 million, or 11.9%, from €393.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2020 to €440.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to a
€41.2 million increase in costs for technical support and consultancy, driven by the increase in revenues
over the same period that required the support of resources external to the Group. Service costs
accounted for 32.3% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared with 33.9% of
our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Personnel costs_

Personnel costs increased by €36.8 million, or 5.8%, from €637.8 million for the year ended December
31, 2020 to €674.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was due primarily to a
reduced use of extraordinary government benefits and compensation schemes in the context of the
COVID-19 pandemic. Personnel costs accounted for 52.3% of our revenues for the year ended
December 31, 2020, compared with 52.0% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Amortization and depreciation_

Amortization and depreciation increased by €35.7 million, or 58.4%, from €61.1 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020 to €96.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was
primarily due to (i) an increased amortization of intangible assets driven by the recognition of customer
lists and relationships on our balance sheet as a result of the purchase price allocation for acquisitions
completed over the period and (ii) and a €0.9 million decrease in amortization costs relating to the
impact of the implementation of the IFRS 16 accounting standard from €19.7 million in 2020 to €18.8
million in 2021. Amortization and depreciation accounted for 5.0% of our revenues for the year ended
December 31, 2020, compared with 7.5% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Provisions_

Provisions increased by €14.0 million, or 160.9%, from €8.7 million for the year ended December 31,
2020 to €22.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to
increased allocations to bad debt provisions due to the write-off of receivables owed by Sicilia e-Servizi
Venture S.c. à r.l. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.” Provisions accounted for 0.7% of our revenues
for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared with 1.7% of our revenues for the year ended
December 31, 2021.

_Other costs_

Other costs increased by €14.0 million, or 133.3%, from €10.5 million for the year ended December 31,
2020 to €24.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to fines
incurred in connection with a reassessment of past income taxes (€4.8 million) and transaction costs
accounted in connection with the acquisition of the 49% minority shareholding in our subsidiary
Cybertech. Other costs accounted for 0.9% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020,
compared with 1.9% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Financial income_

Financial income increased by €3.3 million, or 45.2%, from €7.3 million for the year ended December
31, 2020 to €10.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to
increased gains on exchange differences driven by fluctuations in exchange rates.

_Financial expenses_

Financial expenses increased by €55.9 million, or 349.4%, from €16.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 to €71.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily


-----

due to €58.2 million increased interest expenses, which amounted to €66.6 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021, compared to €8.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, driven by interest
payments over the period for borrowings by the Issuer under the Existing Notes and the Existing Term
Loan, as opposed to lower interest payments made by the Company for the year ended December 31,
2020, reflecting a lower level of Group indebtedness prior to the consummation of the Engineering
Acquisition.

_Income taxes_

Income taxes increased by €94.2 million, or 93.6%, from a credit of €100.6 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 to a credit of €6.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This tax credit
decrease was primarily due to the extraordinary release to the income statement for the year ended
December 31, 2020, of deferred tax liabilities relating to trademarks and other intangible assets, which
was driven by the realignment of the higher value relating to business assets and equity investments
resulting from the financial information for the year ended December 31, 2019, pursuant to Law Decree
no. 104 of 14 August 2020, converted into Law no. 126 of 13 October 2020, and Law no. 178 of 30
December 2020.

_Adjusted EBITDA_

Adjusted EBITDA increased by €21.0 million, or 11.8%, from €177.3 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 to €198.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was
primarily due to positive performance across our Finance, Industry & Services and Health industry
verticals, partly offset by underperformance in our Energy & Utilities industry vertical, compared to the
year ended December 31, 2020. In addition, excluding Adjusted EBITDA generated by our mobile
payments business, our Adjusted EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2021, would have been
€198.7 million, an increase of €21.7 million (or 12.3%) compared to €176.9 million in the year ended
December 31, 2020.
