Adjusted EBITDA in the Finance industry vertical increased by €9.8 million, or 15.5%, from €63.4
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €73.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.
This increase was primarily due to the combined effect of increased sales of Proprietary Solutions
products and a lower volume of sales driven by third-party licenses.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Health industry vertical increased by €4.2 million, or 25.8%, from €16.3
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €20.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.
This increase was primarily due to increased sales volumes driving higher margins.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Industry & Services industry vertical increased by €4.9 million, or 20.2%,
from €24.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €29.2 million for the year ended December
31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to increased efficiency in managing indirect costs and an
increase in sales driven by the global recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Telco & Media industry vertical increased by €2.2 million, or 20.2%, from
€10.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €13.1 million for the year ended December 31,
2021. This increase was primarily due to higher sales margins driven by increased sales to key
customers, partly offset by a decrease in revenues from our mobile payments business. In addition,
Adjusted EBITDA generated from our mobile payments business decreased from €0.5 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020 to negative €0.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, as a
result of the ongoing revenue reduction resulting from restrictions imposed by the competent Italian
authorities on the use of services through such platform by such mobile operators. Excluding Adjusted
EBITDA generated by our mobile payments business, Adjusted EBITDA in our Telco & Media
industry vertical in the year ended December 31, 2021, would have been €13.5 million, an increase of
€3.1 million (or 28.9%) compared to €10.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Energy & Utilities industry vertical decreased by €4.1 million, or 14.0%, from
€29.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €25.2 million for the year ended December 31,
2021. This increase was primarily due to the impact of certain one-off costs recorded on certain
customer projects.

Adjusted EBITDA in the Public Administration industry vertical increased by €3.8 million, or 11.5%,
from €33.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €36.9 million for the year ended December
31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase in sales volumes by our subsidiary Municipia,
driven by a rebound of its tax management business following the recovery from the COVID-19
pandemic.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Overview_**

Historically, the principal sources of our liquidity have been cash flow from operating activities and
bank credit lines, as well as the Existing Revolving Credit Facility since July 10, 2020. In addition, we
engage in the sale of receivables on the basis of uncommitted or committed framework non-recourse
factoring agreements in order to support our working capital and liquidity needs.

On or about September 29, 2022, certain lenders made available an additional facility under the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in a principal amount of €35.0 million by way of a fungible


-----

increase of the total commitments under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility to €195.0 million. See
“Summary—The Existing Revolving Credit Facility Increase,” and “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—Existing Revolving Facility Agreement.” At the end of 2022 we drew €50.0 million_
under our Existing Revolving Credit Facility to fund the acquisition of Atlantic Technologies, which
are outstanding as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. From time to time, we may borrow
amounts under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, among other things, to repay a portion of Be’s
existing indebtedness.

Moreover, we recently revised our prior policy of mainly resorting to spot sales of trade receivables on
a non-recourse basis to support our liquidity needs and, in March 2022, we entered into the First Intesa
Securitization Program, consisting of a new committed framework factoring agreement with a vehicle
controlled by Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. providing for non-recourse sales of receivables for an aggregate
amount of up to €150.0 million at any time outstanding. As of December 31, 2022, €110.7 million were
outstanding under the First Intesa Securitization Program, while €39.3 million were available for
drawing. In addition, in October 2021 we entered into the Second Intesa Securitization Program, which
provides for the non-recourse sales of receivables from Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. For the year ended
December 31, 2022, we have sold €122.6 million trade receivables under the Second Intesa
Securitization Program. See “Description of Certain Other Financing Arrangements—Existing
_Company Indebtedness—Intesa Securitization Programs.” We intend to primarily rely on our operating_
cash flow and on sales of receivables under our Intesa Securitization Programs and on a spot basis, as
well as our Existing Revolving Credit Facility to satisfy our working capital and other liquidity needs
going forward.

As a result of sales of receivables under the Intesa Securitization Programs and other spot sales of
receivables, as of December 31, 2022, as part of our receivables management strategy and to support
our M&A activity we sold €787.8 million of trade receivables on a non-recourse basis, €133.3 million
of which were still outstanding at period end (excluding €121.2 million of trade receivables sold on a
non-recourse basis by Be, €39.6 million of which were still outstanding as of December 31, 2022).

Historically, our principal uses of cash have been, and we expect that our principal uses of cash
following the Transactions will be, to fund capital expenditures, provide working capital, meet debt
service requirements, fund our add-on acquisitions, including funding the payment of earn outs and the
exercise of certain put and call options related to our acquired subsidiaries that have minority
shareholders. We believe that the current cash flow from operating activities and existing bank financing
will provide us with sufficient liquidity to meet current working capital needs.

Our ability to generate sufficient cash for our debt service depends on our operating performance and
liquidity and on the operating performance and liquidity of our subsidiaries, which in turn depends to a
certain extent on general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, many of which are
beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the “Risk Factors.”

_Total cash flow from / (used in) operating activities_

Total cash flow from operating activities increased by €120.9 million, or 81.3%, from an inflow of
€148.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to an inflow of €269.7 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the higher cash collected from the sale of
products and services to third parties, partly offset by higher cash paid for goods and services and for
personnel costs for the year ended December 31, 2022 with were driven by the combined effect of
organic revenue growth and the consolidation of the Be Group and Atlantic Technologies.

Total cash flow from operating activities increased by €81.6 million, or 121.4%, from an inflow €67.2
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to an inflow of €148.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to higher cash collected from the sale of products
and services to third parties as a result of a recovery from COVID-19, partially offset by cash paid for
personnel costs and goods and services.

_Total cash flow from / (used in) investing activities_

Total cash flow used in investing activities increased by €428.8 million, or 463.7%, from an outflow
€93.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to an outflow of €524.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to increased purchase of intangible assets and to
consideration paid for acquisitions.

Total cash flow used in investing activities increased by €57.7 million, or 163.1%, from an outflow of
€35.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to an outflow of €93.1 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021. This increase in outflow was primarily due to higher consideration paid for
acquisitions and increased purchase of intangible assets.

_Total cash flow from / (used in) financing activities_

Total cash flow from financing activities increased by €380.9 million, or 1,170.8%, from an outflow of
€32.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to an inflow of €348.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. This increase in inflow was primarily due to the increase in borrowings under new
loans, which offset the increase in the repayment of borrowings.

Total cash flow used in financing activities decreased by €49.1 million, or 60.1%, from an outflow of
€81.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to an outflow of €32.5 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021. This decrease in outflow was primarily due to a decrease in the repayment of
borrowings.

**_Net Working Capital_**

Net Working Capital represents customer contract assets, inventory, deferred contract costs, trade
receivables and other current assets less trade payables, other current liabilities, current tax payables
and current provision for risks and charges. Net Working Capital is not a measure of net income,
operating income, operating performance or liquidity presented in accordance with IFRS. When
assessing our operating performance, you should not consider this data in isolation or as a substitute for


-----

our net income, operating income or any other operating performance or liquidity measure that is
calculated in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS
_Measures.”_

Change in Net Working Capital represents the difference in Net Working Capital as of the specified
date compared to Net Working Capital as of the comparable prior date. Our Net Working Capital results
are affected by seasonality, with our Net Working Capital levels typically peaking in September of each
year, reflecting our revenue generation pattern, before gradually declining to their low point in
December of each year.

Trade receivables are initially recognized at transaction price, adjusted for directly attributable
transaction costs, and subsequently measured at amortized cost using the effective interest rate method
(i.e., the rate that equalizes the current value of expected cash flows and the carrying amount at the time
of initial recognition), suitably adjusted to take account of any write-downs, by recording a doubtful
debt provision. Trade receivables are included in current assets, with the exception of those falling due
more than twelve months after the reporting date, which are classified as non-current assets. At each
reporting date, financial assets, with the exception of those measured at fair value with a contra-entry
recognized in the income statement, are analyzed to assess the existence of any possible impairment
indicators. IFRS 9 requires the application of a model based on expected losses on receivables. We
apply the simplified approach to estimate expected losses along the receivable useful life and take into
account its historical experience of losses on receivables, adjusted to reflect current conditions and
estimates of future economic conditions. For trade receivables recorded at amortized cost, when an
impairment has been identified, the relevant value is measured as the difference between the asset book
value and the present value of expected future cash flows, discounted at the original effective interest
rate. This value is recognized in the income statement. Receivables sold under our uncommitted
framework non-recourse factoring agreements, pursuant to which the final transfer to the transferee is
carried out in relation to risks and benefits of factored receivables, are derecognized from the financial
statements upon their transfer. See also “—Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements.”

Deferred contract costs represent only costs considered ‘incremental’ and recoverable through the
economic benefits of the contract, in accordance with IFRS 15. Costs that cannot be classified as
‘incremental’, such as costs incurred independently and not related to the acquisition of the contract,
are expensed in the income statement.

We mitigate our exposure to the risks relating to the collection of receivables through constant
monitoring of our commercial exposure and the collection times of receivables, which we track
excluding the effect of non-recourse sales of receivables. For example, we have a dedicated team
focused on receivables collection and our sales representatives’ variable bonus includes DSO annual
targets. See “Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures Regarding Market and Financial Risks—Credit
_Risk.” Excluding the effect of non-recourse sales of receivables, our DSOs in trade receivables_
decreased from 219 days as of December 31, 2021 to 195 days as of December 31, 2022, due to the
combined effect of organic revenue growth and higher collection of outstanding invoices. Including the
effect of non-recourse sales of receivables, our DSOs in trade receivables were 163 days as of December
31, 2022.

**Lease Commitments**

In accordance with IFRS 16, right-of-use assets are initially measured at cost and subsequently
measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses, adjusted for any
remeasurements of the lease liability. The lease liability is initially measured at the present value of the
lease payments not being paid at that date. Subsequently, the lease liability is adjusted for interest and
lease payments, including for the impact of lease modifications. The carrying amount of current and
non-current lease liabilities amounted to €168.9 million, €142.9 million and €157.4 million as of
December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively, such reduction being driven by annual lease payments
made by the Group. For further information, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and
“Capitalization.”

**Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements**

Certain of the contracts with our customers include a product lifetime warranty. As a consequence, in
case of product defects we could incur warranty costs and be required to make indemnity payments to
our customers.

Indemnification accruals in relation to these contracts are based on estimates that can change over time.
In addition, we have entered into certain off-balance sheet exchange rate and guarantee arrangements.
In addition, we also provide certain guarantees with respect to our participation in tender offers, the
entry into certain contracts and in relation to office rental agreements. Such guarantees amounted to
€499.4 million as of December 31, 2022. We also provide bank sureties in favor of other companies
which amounted to €11.1 million as of December 31, 2022 as well as other performance bonds and
other commitments relating our participation in public tenders (so called “bid bonds”), which amounted
to €79.1 million as of December 31, 2022. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and
_Industry—We may be unable to obtain the bid bonds, performance bonds, securities or guarantees we_
_need to compete in certain public tenders or to enter into certain contracts with our private customers,_
_and due to our failure to perform our obligations, counterparties may enforce bid and performance_
_bonds we have posted.”_

Certain minority shareholders of some of our subsidiaries have contractual arrangements with the Group
pursuant to which they may, following the exercise of put options under such contractual arrangements
and subject to certain conditions and timing requirements, require the Group to purchase their minority
stake. As of December 31, 2022, the aggregate amount of our liabilities in connection with such put
options amounted to €2.6 million, in addition to €14.9 million in respect of earn-out liabilities.
Moreover, as of December 31, 2022, Be’s overall liability with respect to put and call options amounted
to €13.5 million (on a discounted basis). The fair value of such liabilities was determined based on the
terms of the contractual arrangements with our relevant minority shareholder.

Historically, we have engaged in the sale of receivables on the basis of uncommitted framework nonrecourse factoring agreements in order to support our working capital and liquidity needs. Typically,
receivables factored through non-recourse factoring transactions are written off from our financial
statements upon their transfer, as all risks and benefits of the factored receivables are irrevocably
transferred to the transferee. As of December 31, 2022, we sold €787.8 million of trade receivables on
a non-recourse basis, €133.3 million of which were still outstanding at period end (excluding €121.2
million of trade receivables sold on a non-recourse basis by Be, €39.6 million of which were still
outstanding as of December 31, 2022). Recently, we revised our prior policy of mainly resorting to spot
sales of trade receivables on a non-recourse basis to support our liquidity needs and, in March 2022, we


-----

entered into the First Intesa Securitization Program, consisting of a new committed framework factoring
agreement with a vehicle controlled by Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. providing for non-recourse sales of
receivables for an aggregate amount of up to €150.0 million at any time outstanding. As of December
31, 2022, €110.7 million were outstanding under the First Intesa Securitization Program, while €39.3
million were available for drawing. In addition, in October 2021 we entered into the Second Intesa
Securitization Program, which provides for the non-recourse sales of receivables from Intesa Sanpaolo
S.p.A. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we have sold €122.6 million trade receivables under the
Second Intesa Securitization Program. See “Description of Certain Other Financing Arrangements—
_Existing Company Indebtedness—Intesa Securitization Programs.”_

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures Regarding Market and Financial Risks**

**_Overview_**

In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to credit risk, liquidity risk, interest rate risk and
capital risk. Our risk management strategy is aimed at minimizing potential effects on our financial
performance. Risk management is centralized in our Finance Department.

This discussion does not address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business,
such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors.”

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is derived from customer receivables, taking the form of the possibility that the
counterparties to our contracts will not fulfill their contractual obligations. To mitigate credit risk related
to commercial counterparties we have put in place procedures aimed at ensuring that product sales are
made to customers who are deemed reliable due to, for example, their high creditworthiness. Credit risk
is further mitigated through constant monitoring of our commercial exposure and the collection times
of receivables, including through the implementation of policies aimed at ensuring the solvency of
customers and at limiting excessive exposure to any particular customer at a given time, by means of
tailored evaluation and monitoring activities. For example, we have a dedicated internal team focused
on receivables collection; our sales representatives’ variable bonus includes DSO annual targets in order
to fully align the corporate structure with such targets. In addition, we have historically engaged in the
sale of receivables on the basis of uncommitted framework non-recourse factoring agreements and, in
2021 and 2022, we have entered into the Intesa Securitization Programs. We believe our credit risk
mitigation techniques are effective. Our clients include leading players in their reference market sectors.
As such, we believe that there is limited risk that such operators will face insolvency, bankruptcy or
other administrative procedures. Any financial assets that we consider of doubtful recoverability are
appropriately allocated to the bad debt provisions. As of December 31, 2022 we recorded allowances
for bad debts with respect to receivables from customers of €81.2 million. As of December 31, 2020,
2021 and 2022, we recorded allowances for bad debts with respect to receivables from customers
(including €37.8 million in connection with SISEV and Sicilia Digitale) of €54.7 million, €57.0 million
and €81.2 million, respectively. See “—Net Working Capital.” For more information please refer to the
notes in our 2022 Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk associated with the ability to meet commitments arising from financial
liabilities. Prudent management of the liquidity risk arising from normal operations requires the
maintenance of an adequate level of cash and the availability of funds obtainable through an adequate
amount of credit lines. We further mitigate liquidity risk by centralizing our treasury function (which
allows for efficient resource management) and by ensuring that we have access to different sources of
financing, with different banking institutions and that there are no significant concentrations of liquidity
risk on the side of both financial assets and the sources of financing. To further mitigate any liquidity
risk, we have implemented a cash pooling approach within the Group. Group’s cash is swept to a single
central bank account held by the Company on a daily basis. We aim to balance our mid-to-long term


-----

financial indebtedness with our operations, which are mostly carried out on the short term, in order to
better manage liquidity peaks when due.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Interest risk consists of exposure to the interest rate risk that arises from the fact that currently a portion
of our debt bears floating interest rates. Fluctuations in market interest rates may affect our results,
indirectly affecting costs and returns of financing and investment transactions. After completion of the
Transactions, we will continue to be exposed to interest rate risk in connection with our financial debt
that remains outstanding, the Notes, the Existing Term Loan and any additional borrowings under the
Existing Revolving Credit Facility. The strategy that we follow for this type of risk-mitigation is one
that aims at mitigating interest rate risk while optimizing debt cost.

For a complete summary of our accounting policies, see the 2022 Audited Financial Statements included
elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

## INDUSTRY AND MARKET OVERVIEW

_In this section, we rely on and refer to information regarding the overall Italian Information and_
_Communications Technology (“ICT”) market as well as the ICT Services and ICT Software & Solutions_
_sub-markets in which we operate and compete. The information regarding the market, industry data_
_and forecasts provided herein are based on our beliefs and estimates, internal company reports,_
_publicly available third-party research, diligence reports and third-party research prepared by third_
_parties in connection with the Transactions and information derived from an industry report that was_
_commissioned from a global consulting company. Unless otherwise stated, the source of all industry_
_metrics, estimates, and projections in this section is Anitec-Assinform’s report “Il Digitale in Italia_
_2022 – Previsioni 2022-2025 e Policy”. This section includes certain technical terms that are commonly_
_used in our industry. See “Glossary of Selected Terms” for a detailed explanation of these terms._

**Overview – “Digital is here to stay”**

COVID-19 has accelerated digitalization in nearly all sectors of the Italian economy, influencing
consumer behavior and social interactions and impacting operating practices at both private businesses
and public sector entities. 2020 was a pivotal year for Italy as the spread of the pandemic mandated the
need for technology solutions to enable business continuity and increased corporate and social
awareness of the strategic role that technology plays for the development of the Italian economy. In
2021, the Italian government adopted several measures to catalyze economic recovery post the
downturn caused by COVID-19, including the adoption of the National Recovery and Resilience Plan
(Piano Nazionale di Ripresa e Resilienza) (“PNRR”). Approved in June 2021 in the wake of the Next
Generation EU, PNRR is an economic recovery package aimed at supporting EU Member States to
recover from the impact of the pandemic at both the European and national level.

The Italian ICT market was estimated at approximately €37.2 billion in the six months ended June 30,
2022, and €75.3 billion in the year ended December 31, 2021, a 3.0% and 5.3% growth compared to
the preceding year periods, respectively. Over the course of the year ended December 31, 2021, and the
year ended December 31, 2022, the Italian market experienced a further increase in the adoption of
digital solutions based on modern technologies that leverage the latest capabilities in digitalization, such
as cloud, big data, artificial intelligence (“AI”), and cybersecurity. Data on investments in digital
technologies indicate that digital ways of working are here to stay. Growth of key digital enabler
technologies such as cloud computing, AI, Blockchain and cybersecurity highlight the momentum of
the sector — between 2022 and 2025, cloud computing, AI, blockchain applications and cybersecurity
are expected to grow by approximately 25%, 21%, approximately 26%, and 14%, respectively.

Following robust recovery in the year ended December 31, 2021, and the year ended December 31,
2022, there has been a marked slowdown in growth globally, which is expected to continue moderating
in the year ended December 31, 2023. According to the International Monetary Fund (“IMF”), global
GDP growth is expected to slow down from 6.3% in the year ended December 31, 2021, and 3.4% in
the year ended December 31, 2022 to 2.8% in the year ended December 31, 2023. Advanced
economies, including Italy, are expected to experience an especially pronounced growth slowdown,
from 3.7% in the year ended December 31, 2022, to 0.7% in the year ended December 31, 2023. In the
year ended December 31, 2022, the development of the Italian digital market reflected this trend. All
sectors were growing in the first six months of 2022 but showed a slower percentage increase than in
the first six months of 2021. The only exception is Network Services, which has had a negative trend
in both semesters. Despite the geopolitical uncertainties as well as inflationary pressure, it is expected
that the digitalization in Italian will continue in the coming years with a renewed impetus to the market,
also supported by the PNRR.

**Characteristics and growth of the Italian ICT market**

The ICT market comprises of five key segments: ICT Services, Software and Solutions, Devices and
Systems, Digital Content and Online Advertising, and Network Services. Within the overall market, we


-----

address the large and faster growing ICT Software & Solutions and ICT Services markets, worth
approximately €22 billion in 2021 (and expected to have grown to €23 billion in 2022) and comprising:

- ICT Software & Solutions, are expected to have grown at a CAGR of 3.5% between 2019 and 2022,
which includes system software (e.g., operating system software such as Windows, Linux, and
Mainframe OS), middleware infrastructure software (e.g., software for network management,
storage management, and system management), and application software (e.g., horizontal software
such as Enterprise Resource Planning (“ERP”), CRM, business intelligence and analytics, unified
communications, and vertical software focused on addressing value chains within a certain industry,
such as healthcare, finance, and banking); and

- ICT Services, are expected to have grown at CAGR of 6.1% between 2019 and 2022, which
includes services for software application development and maintenance, system integration,
technology consulting, training and technical support, cloud computing services (including
Software-as-a-Service), and ICT infrastructure management services.

The six months ended December 31, 2022, were affected by a general deterioration in the Italian
economy, in particular by a decline in household consumption and a slowdown in GDP growth. All in
all, almost all sectors are expected to have grown in 2022, albeit less anticipated in June. The negative
trend for Network Services, already observed in previous years, is predicted to continue.

**Development of the Italian ICT market from 2019 to 2022:**

**__________________________**

Source: Anitec-Assinform November 2022

**Growth trends 2021 compared to 2020**

Devices and systems recorded the highest growth, namely a 9.1% increase reaching from €19.4 billion
in the year ended December 31, 2020, to €21.1 billion in the year ended December 31, 2021, mainly
driven by higher sales of personal computers and TV sets. ICT Software and solutions grew by 8%,
from €7.5 billion in the year ended December 31, 2020, to €8.1 billion in the year ended
December 31, 2021. ICT Services grew by 7.6%, from €12.7 billion in the year ended
December 31, 2020, to €13.7 billion in the year ended December 31, 2021, following the resumption of
investments in system integration services and the significant growth in cloud computing and
cybersecurity services. Investments in digital content and advertising also increased, mainly driven by
increased advertising spend on internet platforms.

Overall, the following initiatives and drivers were key elements for accelerating digital investments:


-----

- Companies seeking to create new business models and revenue streams to compensate for revenue
losses caused mainly by the COVID-19 pandemic;

- ICT infrastructure readiness to support new business models (e.g., hybrid working);

- Increased digital interactions with partners and customers and the urge to digitize processes; and

- Robust cybersecurity tools to protect data and applications are required alongside accelerating
digitalization

**Expected trends from 2022 to 2025 show continued growth of the Italian digital market**

Forecasts of the digital market until 2025 are conditioned to be affected not only by particularly
pessimistic macroeconomic situation, but also by the size of projects funded by the PNRR for digital
transformation of public administration and the production system, the impact of which is not yet
possible to be fully determined. Against this background, however, the Italian digital market is expected
to grow slightly in the year ending December 31, 2023, compared to the year ended December 31, 2022,
from €79.1 billion by 3%, or approximately €2.3 billion, to €81.4 billion.

With the launch of new applications, infrastructure and digital transformation projects, in many cases
linked to the resources made available by the PNRR, the market-share of ICT Software & Solutions
and ICT Services is expected to increase. In the year ending December 31, 2023, the first segment is
expected to experience a positive trend, mainly in the Middleware and IT Security segments. ICT
Services will continue to benefit primarily from an increase in applications digitization and
replatforming projects, as well as from a transformation aimed at supporting the cloud migration.

The cloud is expected to continue growing by 25%, given its central role in the digital transformation
of companies and its stated role in the digital transition of the Italian public administration sector.
Overall, ICT Services are expected to reach a significant value of €20 billion by 2025. Investment in
Digital Advertising will also increase in the wider market segment of Digital Content and Advertising,
which is expected to reach €15.4 billion in 2023 (representing a 6.1% growth compared to 2022).

**The importance of the PNRR**

Italy’s commitment to its digital transformation is concrete and critically supported by the PNRR. The
total PNRR resources will be allocated towards six distinct missions: Mission 1 on digitization,


-----

innovation, competitiveness, culture, and tourism; Mission 2 on green revolution and ecological
transition; Mission 3 on infrastructure for sustainable mobility; Mission 4 on education and research;
Mission 5 on inclusion and cohesion; and Mission 6 on healthcare. Digitization represents the first of
the six missions, which accounts for approximately 27% of the total PNRR funding.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Italy has been progressing with its PNRR objectives,
meeting all 51 milestones and targets set for 2021 and all 83 milestones and 17 targets set for 2022.
Overall, Italy has received €42 billion in payments in grants and loans based on milestones and targets
achieved in the first and second tranches. The country expects to be disbursed another €19 billion in
grants and loans for the third tranche, covering various reforms (e.g., areas of primary and secondary
education system, tax courts and administration, annual competition laws) and investments (e.g., digital
infrastructure, cybersecurity and smart grids _(Source: European Parliamentary Research Service,_

focusing on digital investments and R&D. The Group’s products and services can serve multiple

technologies, such as cloud, cybersecurity, and AI, the Group can help businesses and the public
administration realize a wide range of PNRR projects. For instance, among the various PNRR
objectives, digital citizenship spans across multiple missions, such as smart government in Mission 1,

Italy’s ambition to aggressively pursue digitalization is evidenced by the government’s planned reforms
to facilitate the PNRR investments. A total of 63 reforms, both structural and regulatory, aspire to
remove procedural obstacles and simplify the bureaucracy to ensure greater flexibility in the execution
of the plan. Among others, those reforms concern competition, health, labor and tax.

**Digital Market Forecast Scenarios and PNRR Impact**

The development of the digital market in Italy until 2025 will increasingly be affected by ICT
investments financed through and supported by the PNRR. Areas such as public administration will see
clear benefits as 27% of the PNRR budget is earmarked for its digitization. Similarly, digital health
market is being driven by investments under objective 6 of the PNRR. However, not all ICT investments


-----

implemented through the availability of PNRR resources should be considered as incremental to the
ICT market, as some of these initiatives are already planned and PNRR may be used to help finance
their implementation.

**The macro-economic environment and the correlation with the ICT industry**

After the COVID-19 driven decline in 2020, Italy experienced a significant economic recovery in 2021.
In 2021, Italy implemented the PNRR, which boosted the country’s commitment to accomplish its
digital transformation, which represents the first of the missions identified by the PNRR. From a
regulatory and political point of view at EU and national level, the response to the COVID-19
challenges, such as the Recovery Plan for Europe and the PNRR in Italy, places ICT technologies at the
heart of an ambitious ten-year vision for successful digital transformation by 2030. The next generation
EU instrument aims to make the economy more sustainable, resilient and better prepared for the future.
The technologies for digital transformation are critical to achieving this. Digitization is fundamental to
the growth, economic development, and development of companies across all economic sectors. In the
year ended December 31, 2021, the Italian GDP rebounded, growing by 6.6% compared to the previous
year, driven by both consumption and investments. While IT spending as a percentage of the Italian
GDP has been historically lower than other European countries, the digital market witnessed a healthy
growth of 5.3% in the year ended December 31, 2021, contributing 4.2% to the Italian GDP. The digital
market was expected to have grown by 2.1% in the year ended December 31, 2022, contributing
approximately 4.0% to the Italian GDP

**Indicators and benefits of the business digitalization**

A 2022 investment survey carried out by the European Investment Bank indicates greater optimism on
the investment prospects of Italian companies. In the current survey, more Italian firms (85%) were
investing than they were compared to the previous survey (80%). Similarly, despite repeated economic
shocks in 2021-2022 (e.g., COVID-19 and the Ukrainian conflict), Italian firms’ pace of innovation has
not been impacted. In 2022, almost half (47%) of Italy’s firms developed or introduced new products,
processes or services as part of their investment activities, similar to the results of 2021’s investment
survey (46%) and higher than the EU average (34%). However, the number of companies expecting


-----

investments to increase, rather than decline, stood at approximately 16%, a decline from 24% in the
prior year’s survey and close to the EU average (net balance of 20%). The share of investments for the
year ended December 31, 2022, in machinery and equipment is significant (representing approximately
51% of the total investments). In addition, investments in intangible assets (R&D, software, Data, IT
activities, websites and training and business processes) remained relatively stable at 38% of total
investments compared to the year ended December 31, 2021.

**Breakdown of investments made by Italian companies between 2019 and 2022**

**___________________________**
Source: Anitec Assinform 2022, European Investment Bank Investment Survey, 2022 and 2021

Companies in the services sector, are increasing their investments in software, IT, and data with the
latter being essential for analyzing and segmenting customers. Investments in digital technologies
regarding processes and data are also made by manufacturing companies and large businesses, which
also continue to have the highest share of investments in R&D. To this end, the PNRR is expected to
critically support the digitization of manufacturing plants. Analysis carried out by the European
Investment Bank in its 2022 investment survey, shows that, approximately 55% of Italian firms have
taken action in response to COVID-19; the survey notes that the most frequent response, especially
among large firms, has been to become more digital (41% vs. 53% EU). Moreover, approximately 68%
of the Italian companies are using at least one advanced digital technology, in line with EU average.
Companies are also demonstrating an increased awareness of security risks due to the exponential
growth of cyber threats, which have driven both large and small companies to adopt adequate defense
capabilities.

E-commerce also experienced strong tailwinds due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and it is now central
in the new buying habits of consumers. In the year ended December 31, 2021, online purchases in Italy
reached a total of €39.4 billion, which represents a 21% increase compared to total online purchases in
the year ended December 31, 2020. Consequently, businesses at large have moved to launching online
sales channels, which resulted in a 17.5% increase in the share of business sales from online sales
between the year ended December 31, 2019, and 2021.

tendency towards cloud, cybersecurity and data management and analysis, which is expected to further
reduce the growth gap between the traditional ICT sector and the digital market, underpinned by digital
transformation of the more traditional components of the market such as network, systems, and

**Deep dive into key Digital Enablers**

Cloud computing continued its growth trajectory, confirming that it is one of the main technologies
enabling digital transformation and innovation of business models. Companies are increasingly
investing in cloud technologies and architectures to modernize applications and systems, leverage
scalability, flexibility, and reduce time to market when launching new products and services.

**Cloud computing market growth between 2019 and 2021**

## ____________________
Source: Anitec-Assinform 2022


-----

While in the year ended December 31, 2020 growth was mainly driven by activities to respond to
COVID-19 and enable business continuity via remote activities, in the year ended December 31, 2021
showed a continuous trend of increased awareness of the need of digital for companies, which
understood that the transition to the cloud is essential to reach the scalability and reactivity levels that
the market requires to remain competitive. Such awareness has translated into cloud migration plans
across businesses in various sectors.

At the same time, with the implementation of a strategy for a national cloud and approximately €1
billion budgeted by the PNRR, cloud has become an enabling platform for digitization of public
administration. Private and Virtual Private Cloud are models that affect more traditional organizations
or companies that need to maintain data and applications within proprietary datacenters or in dedicated
areas at cloud datacenters. In the year ended December 31, 2021, the growth of these models has been
moderate, at a rate of 11% and 14.7%, respectively compared to the previous year. The Infrastructureas-a-Service (“IaaS”) cloud represents the largest share of the total cloud market with a 52.7% share,
followed by the Software-as-a-Service (“SaaS”) which holds a 41% share. Platform-as-a-Service
(“PaaS”), which requires a high level of customization and is mainly used for data applications analytics
and AI, is still limited relative to the others.

**Big Data**

Data is a strategic asset for all businesses. The value of the big data industry exceeded €1.3 billion in
the year ended December 31, 2021, a 15.4% increase compared to the year ended December 31, 2020.
Double-digit growth in spending on solutions and services for optimal data management is a result of
greater awareness of Italian companies that need to be able to guarantee adequate governance. The
methods and systems used to extract knowledge from structured data, plays a key role in improving
competitiveness, resilience, and decision-making processes.

**Cybersecurity**

The cybersecurity market is estimated to have experienced a double-digit growth of 13% in the year
ended December 31, 2022 and was valued approximately €1.6 billion. 2022 saw an increase in cyberattacks with the highest number of attacks ever seen at 225 in March 2022 alone. “Hacktivism” saw a
4x increase, followed by the ‘Information Warfare’ category, growing at 119%. Espionage (+62%
compared to the first half of 2021) was another reason for growth in number of cyber-attacks.

**Evolution of the cybersecurity market from 2019 to 2022 (expected)**

Source: Anitec-Assinform 2022

All segments are expected to have grown in the year ended December 31, 2022, with managed security
services (“MSS”) expected to have experienced the highest growth rate, of 15.4% in the year ended
December 31, 2022, and an annual average growth rate of 16.7%. However, demand for MSS is
reducing because of a need to address the shortage of resources and the use of external security and
operations control center 24x7 services.


-----

The second segment, in order of market relevance, is System Integration and other services, expected
to have grown by 12.1% in 2022, reaching almost €600 million. There is an increased adoption of
identity and access governance solutions, required to be strengthened to manage the transition to the
hybrid working model in a secure manner. In the area of software solution implementation
infrastructure, the Endpoint Detection & Response and the SIEM solutions are also expected to grow
to monitor the extended perimeter, which is more and more beyond that of the individual company.

Consultancy services (Advice), although expected to have a low overall market share at €86 million in
2022, are expected to have grown at a high rate (annual average growth rate increasing by 13.1%) with
the most popular category being Risk and Vulnerability Assessment.

**Artificial Intelligence (AI) / Cognitive**

In the year ended December 31, 2021, spending rebounded and the market resumed its growth trajectory
at a rapid pace, reaching approximately €330 million, which represented a 31.5% increase compared to
the year ended December 31, 2020. The main driver for such increase was the realization that AI
technologies can deliver competitive advantages by supporting strategic decision-making and
improving operational efficiencies (i.e., failure and downtime prevention, streamlining repetitive tasks,
improving security, and compliance). Currently, there is a significant divide in AI investments between
large companies and Small Medium Enterprises (“SMEs”), but the adoption of AI from SMEs is
expected to increase, mainly driven by the development of the Italian Strategy for Artificial Intelligence,
which outlines the policies to be implemented in next three years aiming to enhance the artificial
intelligence system in Italy.

**The Internet of Things (IoT)**

The IoT market in Italy resumed its growth in the year ended December 31, 2021 after the setback in
the year ended December 31, 2020, reaching a market value of over €3.7 billion, representing a 9.9%

projects that were postponed in 2020 mainly due to the COVID-19-related restrictions. Furthermore,
growth was also fueled by services trials of remote assistance and monitoring of COVID-19 patients in
the healthcare space, catalyzing the development of telemedicine services. The evolution of IoT related

smart factories, telemedicine, smart cities and smart grids.

**Digital transformation trends in the main economic sectors**

Public administration and Health are two sectors where spending on digital technology is expected to
be more intensive, above the overall average. This trend reflects the PNRR’s planning for digitization
and innovation of public entities and companies in the healthcare sector, whereas the banks, industrials,
defense, and insurance sectors are broadly in line with the average spend. In the financial sector, banking
groups are emphasizing new business models based on open finance, while insurance companies are
investing to outweigh delays in digitization which has traditionally characterized the industry. The
industrial sector, despite the difficult economic context, is likely to benefit from the launch of direct
investments targeted at optimizing core processes to increase competitiveness.

**Expected growth for selected industry sectors from 2022 to 2025**

In the year ended December 31, 2021, all sectors showed positive trends, driven by the resumption of
investments and the growing need of companies to adapt to new and emerging operating models. During
the year ended December 31, 2020, most of the companies were forced to take measures to ensure
business continuity, which led to greater awareness of the strategic nature of digital technologies, not
only to support a company’s success, but also to sustain Italy’s competitiveness. Consequently,
spending and investments increased across all sectors in the year ended December 31, 2021, mainly in
respect of public administration and health. Cloud technologies, automation of processes and services,
cybersecurity, data governance and the modernization of architectures and data management platforms
represent the main investment drivers across all areas.

**Banks**

The banking sector grew by 8.2% in the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to an expectation of
5.6% in the year ended December 31, 2022. This growth was driven by the restart of modernization
plans that involve digitalization and updating of the information systems as well as new initiatives to
support the transition towards innovative operating and business models, where digital technologies
play both an enabling and strategic role. Customer behavior has evolved, shifting to digital channels as
opposed to physical branches for transactional operations and other activities. Such behavior
accelerated downsizing of bank branches — which totaled approximately 23.5 thousand by the year
ended on December 31, 2020, with further closures expected to have occurred throughout 2022 — and
has induced even the most traditional banks to direct their customer services onto digital platforms. This
transition has been resulting in fintech services having been integrated within the banks’ business
models, with most of them partnering with fintech businesses and in large part investing in such fintech
companies.

In the near future, digitization is expected to become one of the strongest drivers in the evolution of the
operating models and services of financial institutions, as evidenced by the trend and plans of leading
banking groups. In this regard, architectural evolution, cloud, and application renewal are indispensable


-----

ingredients for digital transformation, to ensure flexibility and optimal user experience across all
channels. Many banks are overcoming resistance to cloud adoption, which was mainly coming from the
need to keep their data within the European territory, as a result the choice of some of the main
Hyperscalers to create their own infrastructure in Italy. The transition to the cloud, with the adoption of
a hybrid multicloud model has been undertaken mainly by large banks and involves complex project
management considering the legacy architecture that characterizes traditional banking operations. Such
projects are expected to start with the modernization of applications through containerization, and then
progressively result in a shift of most applications onto the cloud.

In addition, cybersecurity represents a further high priority investment, which has always captured a
significant portion of banks’ IT budgets. The primary area of investment is expected to focus on
strengthening endpoint security and access from a ZeroTrust perspective, together with secure by design
approach, which means that software products and capabilities have been designed to be foundationally
secure. Data governance and, in general, the evolution of data architecture will also be high priority
areas of investment and will be instrumental to reengineering certain processes (e.g., providing credit
to a customer) and to the personalization of customer services and relationships.

**High priority investment areas in the banking sector in 2021 and 2022**

**___________________________**
Source: Anitec-Assinform 2022

For banks, the expectation has been for a growth demand of 5.6% for the year ended
December 31, 2022, entailing the market reaching a total size of €9.1 billion. Demand has been further
expected to growth by 7% in the year ended December 31, 2023. The industry has continued to invest
in digital as a lever for transforming business and labor-market models. Italian banks, having
demonstrated strong resilience in the pandemic period, by focusing on digital to ensure continuity of
service to their customers, gained a greater awareness in the year ended December 31, 2022 of the
potential of digital technology to support their strategies and the need to renew their architectures to
innovate organizational models and to compete in a market environment of increasing challenges. The
transition to the Cloud and the evolution of data architectures and Analytics are part of the strategic
plans of the main Italian banks. Transforming customer relationships into a hybrid model also requires
a continuous strengthening of cybersecurity to ensure secure access to banking services while providing
the best customer experience. Business modernization remains one of the main areas of investment.

**Insurance**

Digital demand in the insurance and finance sectors is forecast to grow by +4.7% (€2.4 billion) in the
year ended December 31, 2022 and 5.3% in the year ended December 31, 2023 (€2.6 billion),
respectively. A key area of investment is digitization of customer relationships, at all stages of


-----

contractual relationship. Robotic process automation is an additional priority investment area which
aims at achieving greater operational efficiency, with projects focused on back-office process
automation, such as claims management, after-sales and administration, and finance. Investment in
cybersecurity, like in banking, is also seeing a rise in insurance.

**Industry & Services**

Industrial companies have been experiencing a period of high uncertainty, mainly due to the persistence
of the COVID-19 pandemic and, more recently, the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, which has led to a sharp
rise in agricultural, metals, and energy prices.

Between the fourth quarter of 2021 and the first quarter of 2022, approximately 70% of the total
investments were dedicated to the acquisition of functional machinery for digitization, compared to
approximately 30% for traditional machinery. As a result, digital spending in the industrial sector
amounted to €8.5 billion, a 7.9% increase compared to 2020. The digital investments in the sector are
also expected to be supported by PNRR resources in connection with the so-called transition 4.0. In
particular, industrial companies are expected to benefit in terms of R&D, innovation, and functional
training programs, aiming to provide the necessary digital skills and know-how to enable industry 4.0,
with the main areas of investment expected to be in cybersecurity, as cyber-attacks on companies are
progressively increasing.

During the year ended December 31, 2021, digital spending has been sustained by operators in the
distribution and services sector, which has recorded a substantial recovery over the previous year, up to
over €4.6 billion, a 7% increase compared to the year ended December 31, 2020. The last two years
ended December 31, 2022 saw a profound digital transformation in the sector, which became essential
to ensure the operational continuity of the distribution of necessities and to cope with intermittent
closures imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic. E-commerce and fast delivery have proved to be
indispensable levers to compete on the market. While in the year ended December 31, 2020 retailers
had to find workarounds against lockdowns, in 2021 such issues were addressed in a more structured
way, becoming essential priorities guiding the digital transformation plans for the sector. In terms of
2021 priorities, digitization projects around solutions for the digital customer is seen as the main
investment area, coupled with the optimization of e-commerce processes and innovation of marketing
and loyalty campaigns.


-----

**Telco & Media**

Telco and Media market size was €9.3 billion in the year ended December 31, 2021, a 6.3% increase
compared to the year ended December 31, 2020. Overall, the market has benefitted from smart working
solutions deployed by a number of companies and entities of the public administration. Such policies
have allowed a substantial increase of broadband connections to adequately meet the needs of remote
workers. The market is showing signs of resilience and growth, evidencing its critical role in the overall
Italian economy. Between 2010 and 2021, the share of the population with access to the Internet
increased from approximately 52% to approximately 82%. To support the demand for connectivity,
operators had to invest significantly in growing the network and related services. In the last decade, the
overall investments of the sector amounted to approximately €65 billion, allowing the country to largely
bridge the gap with the rest of Europe in terms of population reached by bandwidth services. The main
digital projects conducted in the Telco & Media sector include big data and data management,
cybersecurity and a whole set of application modernization solutions that also involve cloud SaaS
projects. The sector is particularly involved in digital infrastructure projects envisaged by the PNRR,
such as “Connected School”, “Connected Health” and “Italy 5G”, with a total estimated investment
need of approximately €9.1 billion.

During the year ended December 31, 2022, the telecommunications and media sector has reached an
overall digital spending of €9.5 billion, a growth of 1.5% compared to the year ended
December 31, 2021, which has slowed sharply compared to previous years. The spending is being
distributed on several fronts but is now clustered by two prevailing strands. On the one hand, the need
to extend the communication infrastructure across Italy, with the need to maintain a high flow of
investment. On the other hand, the need to speed up the process of modernizing technology envelopes,
which has been repeatedly postponed and which is even more necessary at this particular historical
moment, where maintaining old systems can be a resource-intensive process. With regards to the
specific technology areas covered by the most relevant projects, the ten-digit increase in the use of cloud
architectures, particularly in the presence of technological refreshes, is confirmed, in addition to the
increase in the use of intelligent business solutions to better intercept the needs of customers (Media)
and to prevent the intention of changing the provider (Telco).

**Energy and Utilities**

Digital spending in the utility sector is also estimated to be growing in the year ended
December 31, 2022, albeit slowing down compared to performance in the year ended
December 31, 2021. The market has been expected to reach a size of €2.1 billion in the year ended
December 31, 2022, compared to a size of €2.0 billion in the year ended December 31, 2021 and
representing a 3.7% increase. The increase in energy prices and the increased risks from NPL (for
coverage and credit), price cap and untying of gas prices and the search for alternative sources of energy
are expected to have had an impact on the slowdown. In addition, supply routes for full energy transition
and electrification, as promoted by the UN Sustainable Development Goal and the European Green
Deal, are limited. During the year ended December 31, 2022, and in particular in the six months ended
December 31, 2022, the focus of business in this sector was on modernizing processes and improving
efficiencies, but also on customer care. The projects re-look at the implementation modernization,
including the deployment of micro-service platforms, as well as the more intensive and comprehensive
use of the Cloud, in infrastructure and application (including and especially in CRM) to make the
enterprise flexible and flexible in its ability to respond to changing circumstances. Together, there is a
strong focus on investment in digitization of networks, on smart meters, for the collection of supplies
to energy production plants, for predictive maintenance of networks and facilities and asset
management. In several cases, we are starting to see the flourishing of Digital Twin solutions for
modeling the operation of gas and energy plants and networks. Increasing consideration is given to
investments in BI/Analytics for the re-establishment of a data management architecture that ensures
data quality at all business levels and enables scenario formulation. Investments in Cybersecurity,
including attacks during the day-to-day, are crucial and continuous, in order to build a security by design


-----

at all levels, including the components of Network and IOT. With projects targeting identity
governance, strengthening disaster recovery and business continuity solutions.

**Public Administration**

In the year ended December 31, 2021, the public administration made progresses in digitization
projects, with spending by the central public administration increasing by 9.4%, and local public
administration spend reaching €1.4 billion, representing a 9% growth compared to the year ended
December 31, 2020. Most of the projects focused on the implementation of the objectives of the threeyear plan for IT of the public administration and, in particular, on the evolution of citizen services with
a view to digital and mobile first and on the adoption of main digital enabling platforms. The PNRR
has emphasized the role of digitization of the public administration to ensure competitiveness of the
Italian economy. Mission 1 under the PNRR foresees a €6.1 billion total spend on the digitization of
procedures and processes, the strengthening of cybersecurity and the implementation of the national
cloud strategy. Investments financed through the PNRR are expected to support the digital market for
the public administration in the coming years, with most of the projects starting in the year ended
December 31, 2023. Cybersecurity constitutes a further cornerstone of Mission 1 under the PNRR, with
investments expected to amount to approximately €623 million, of which €194 million in the year ended
December 31, 2022, including the costs related to the establishment of the National Cybersecurity
Agency and the introduction of new personnel in the areas of public security and judicial police for the
prevention and investigation of cybercrime.

**Healthcare**

During the year ended December 31, 2021, the healthcare sector transitioned from a phase of
experimentation to one of designing structured digital projects, which supported the sector’s continued
growth path. The health sector saw an increase of 8.8% in the digital market, from €1.9 billion in the
year ended December 31, 2021 to €2.0 billion in the year ended December 31, 2022, a slightly shrinking
trend compared to the two-year period before the cedar era, which experienced a 9.6% growth. In
addition, the market is expected to grow further in the year ending December 31, 2023 (for a growth of
10.5%, or €2,250 million). To overcome secular inefficiencies, the PNRR dedicates an entire mission
to Italy’s health system, allocating more than €20 billion to investments targeting the development of
local health and the digital evolution of the sector. The development of the digital health market is
driven by investments under objective 6 of the PNRR.

In particular, the main digital challenges set forth by the national plan in the health area concern the
evolution of the Electronic Health Record (“ESF”), with the objective of:

- making such record system an ecosystem of data and services supporting citizens, health workers,
public bodies, and researchers;

- setting up a telemedicine network, spreading from the national platform into all territories and
forming the basis of new community medicine; and

- modernizing the medical equipment.

An analysis on a significant sample of health companies, public and private hospitals, and regions,
showed that the primary area of focus for intervention should be telemedicine. Moreover, the
enhancement of the Electronic Medical Record represents a further area of investment activity,
emphasizing the need to implement digital solutions at the hospital level.

**Expected growth of the ICT Services and ICT Software & Solutions markets between 2021 and**
**2025**

The ICT Services and ICT Software & Solutions combined market is expected to grow up to a market
value exceeding €30 billion in 2025, at a CAGR of approximately 8.4% from €21.8 billion in 2021 to
€29.7 billion in 2025.

Source: Anitec-Assinform 2022

**The Italian ICT Services market**

The Italian ICT Services market can be divided into four major service segments:

- Application Development and System Integration, which consists of designing or modernizing
applications through new digital technologies and development methods;

- Managed IT, which includes, among others, the management of existing applications and data
center services;

- Cloud Computing, which relates to both public and hybrid cloud computing services, including
IaaS, PaaS and SaaS; and


-----

- Other services, which consists of helpdesk services and other technical support functions.

Among these segments, the Group operates in Application Development, Cloud Computing and
Managed IT services.

There are two main growth drivers in the Italian ICT services market, namely an increasing penetration
of IT services in Italy, and an ongoing process of digitalization, characterized by a digital transformation
of traditional IT to new digital enabling technologies, an increased interaction among partners and
customers while implementing the digitalization of the processes, and the ICT infrastructure readiness
to support new business models. Digital transformation is driving the growth in every sector,
determining cost savings and automation. The ICT Services market amounted to approximately €13.7
billion in the year ended December 31, 2021, a 7.6% increase compared to the year ended
December 31, 2020. Within this market, cloud experienced the highest growth and increased by 24.4%
compared to the previous year up to €4.2 billion. Demand for cloud services is growing, across various
economic areas and supported by both large companies and SMEs, which are gradually turning to it.

**Growth in the Italian ICT services market from 2020 to 2021**

Source: Anitec-Assinform 2022

Data center-related services decreased by 2.2% in the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the
previous year, mainly as a result of increased focus on cloud-related services, with Cloud Computing
Services overcoming the ICT Outsourcing services market. This decreasing trend of the ICT
Outsourcing services market is further driven by the increase in Software maintenance service, which
grew by 4.9% compared to the year ended December 31, 2020, and services management of
telecommunications components, whereas the markets for processing services and IT outsourcing
services decreased by 3.8% and 0.2% over the same period, respectively.

Development and system integration services showed a sustained recovery with an increase of 3.8% in
the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the previous year, up to €3.1 billion. The restart of
projects in many sectors and the strong trend towards digitization, emerges from the progress of the
infrastructural projects and application projects which increased by 3.5% and 5.3%, respectively, over
the same period. Custom software also registered a 5.1% growth in the year ended December 31, 2021
compared to the previous year. The reaction to the emergency stemming from the COVID-19 pandemic
supported a continued focus on activities towards business continuity, with a slowdown or, in many
cases, the interruption of projects related to the evolution and modernization of vertical applications.
During the year ended December 31, 2021, the market rebounded with investments in cybersecurity,
big data architectures and, accordingly, in advanced analytics. Large companies have also initiated
projects to implement robotic process automation.


-----

Consulting services grew by 5.6% in the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the previous year,
mainly due to digital and cloud transformation projects. Application investments, on the other hand,
confirm an ever-increasing need for solutions for digital customers and, more generally, for application
modernization projects dedicated to the functional and operational integration of the existing systems
with cloud environments, which are now available to almost all the large information systems.

**The Italian ICT Software and Solutions market**

The Italian Software and Solutions market is composed of the following segments:

- Application Software, which can be further segmented into vertical focused industry solutions,
horizontal software solutions, including ERP and CRM software, and various digital application
software, including cloud, web, IoT;

- Infrastructure Software (or middleware), which includes IT management and governance tools,
infrastructure management, storage, security and information management, development and
integration platforms; and

- System Software, which includes operating system and network operating system software.

The Group focuses on the Application Software segment, with a suite of vertical focused industry
solutions and horizontal software solutions dedicated to the Italian corporate market.

At the end of 2021, the Italian Software and Solutions market rebounded to pre-pandemic levels,
growing by 8% compared to 2020, mainly due to a noteworthy increase of expenditure in Application
Software, which is in turn driven by direct investments in smart business / IoT platforms. In particular,
such projects mainly focus on the industrial sectors, such as retail, utilities and transportation, where
optimization of production management, transportation, warehousing, and other facilities is of utmost
importance.

**The Italian Software and Solutions market from 2019 to 2021**

__________________________
Source: Anitec-Assinform 2022

Investments in web management platforms reflect the increasing importance of an effective online
presence, supporting e-commerce and broader solutions for commercial processes as well as emerging
business models based on multi-channels.

Horizontal and vertical solutions also grew in the year ended December 31, 2021, even if at a slower
pace, in line with the strong setbacks experienced in the year ended December 31, 2020. In the year


-----

ended December 31, 2021, the recovery in investments concerned business intelligence and analytics
solutions and technical applications, to support management of the operations in many sectors and of
vertical applications, which aim to help a company’s core business processes. The horizontal solutions,
mainly consisting of individual productivity suites, ERP, and main solutions of extended-ERP, are
expected to continue to suffer from growing maturity and progressive migration to the cloud, also due
to the persistent smart working environment that mandates more technologically advanced solutions.
The development of the middleware software is supported by the need of companies to protect and
better organize their information assets and to manage the growing heterogeneity and hybridization of
infrastructures. Lastly, system software started growing again especially in the operating systems. PC
and laptop’s operating systems continue to struggle, although mildly compared to 2020 when companies
had focused on the purchase of new devices and systems rather than updating their operating platforms.

**Leading positioning in a highly competitive market**

The Italian market is fragmented with large local Italian players such as Engineering and Reply, and
Italian businesses of global players such as Accenture and IBM, enjoying strong market positions across
verticals, followed by a long tail of smaller local providers. Across sectors where it operates, such as
financial institutions, energy, and industry, Engineering has been supporting firms with their core
processes establishing deep relationships with its clients by providing end-to-end services, from strategy
creation to implementation, positioning itself as a one-stop-shop for clients’ key digital needs. As the
next phase of digital transformation is moving from non-core to core process, the Group is well
positioned to support firms with their core transformation initiatives which will be critical for their
future success.

Additionally, given the uncertain macroeconomic environment, employing and retaining individuals
has become challenging. In the face of such challenges, the Group has benefitted from its initiative of
upskilling and re-skilling its employees. Students from universities and schools are recruited directly
from campus and upskilled through various training programs. Such a move has assisted Engineering
in being able to employ over 1,500 people throughout 2022, in a market where there has been a
widespread shortage of talented resources.

The Italian ICT Services market presents some unique characteristics that differentiate it from other
European analogous markets, and constitute significant barriers to entry for potential competitors,
particularly those operating in other European markets, including:

- Italian identity (including the knowledge of the Italian language, which represents an important
advantage of domestic players vis-à-vis foreign competitors);

- In-depth knowledge of local market dynamics and regulatory environment;

- Strong historical relationships with customers, coupled with the complexities and high costs
normally associated with switching IT service provider; and

##  Proximity to customers, which allows IT service providers to be responsive to customers’ needs.

The combination of these characteristics makes it difficult for foreign competitors, including large
Indian IT outsourcing companies, to enter the Italian ICT Services market, and represents a significant
competitive advantage for local players as demonstrated by the relatively high proportion of revenues
they generate.

**Financial services ICT market**

Source: Anitec-Assinform November 2022

According to information derived from a global consulting company industry report, the perspectives
for the ICT market in the financial services sector follow three trends, namely platforms and ecosystems,
the legacy replacement and the enhancement of multichannels. With regards platforms and ecosystems,
technology is becoming a platform game, where “buy” wins over “make”. The trends show that custom
solutions will be replaced by standard software and the cloud adoption will increase mainly driven by
PaaS use, while system integrators will remain essential to transition in such platforms. The second
trend concerns the transition to a “digital” legacy. Cloud, in all its forms, and the services related thereto
are substituting the standard way to do software and infrastructure as Saas, PaaS and Iaas are becoming
normality. Moreover, digital platforms are in turn the legacy of customized solutions and hyperscalers
and large players are betting to build an “as a service” capacity in Italy. Lastly, Italian banks need to
enhance their multichannel to close the user experience and functional gaps compared to the other
European Union competitors. Among the various initiatives, banks are expected to review their
customer journey and mobile core system, make services instant, implement technology in order to fully
intermediate easy to complex interactions, and modern front-ends paramount.
